[h1] Crysis Remastered Review [/h1]
[hr] [/hr]
[b] Explanation: [/b] 
  I've been a fan of this game since I tried it in 2010. It was she who made me leave PS2 for PC. So I played the 2007 original (luckily I have it) to be as objective as possible. I played both games on "SWAT" difficulty in hopes of fixing the problems that the original 2007 version had.

[b] First impression: [/b] 
   It's cool to go back in time. Such familiar cards, as if they had never left them and the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ balance of opponents (the enemy in the cap can withstand 5 blows to the head or dies immediately) Eh... MEMORIES!!!

[b] Half of the game completed: [/b] 
  Controlling the suit from part 2 is very inconvenient (for the reason that the developers didn’t just cut out one mechanic and replace it with another, but put two on top of each other (they conflict with each other), so I returned the controls to the completely original ones (although I think the controls are the second part is the best). The problem of the original with the strange use of processor cores has been solved, but added “probably for balance” optimization problems have been . Played on graphics settings (CAN IT RUN CRYSIS?) with Ray tracing and immediately my video card (2060 super) transferred me from the native resolution (4K) to FullHD. On FullHD, stays around 57-53 FPS. In a battle and with high dynamics, it drops to 47-44 FPS. You can turn off “Rays”, then you will get +10 fps, but the shadows and lighting greatly lose their beauty, and sometimes even the shadows of the guys, which hurts the eyes. You can also turn on "DLSS", you will also get an increase of +30-40 FPS, but the picture loses a lot in detail and smoothing. I played with on "Rays" and "DLSS" are disabled. So the minimum optimization requirements are still lacking. The enemies hit much harder than in the original, it feels like I'm going against them with my bare ass, and not in an armored suit. Also, the suit’s energy is consumed faster, so you have to sit out more often to charge (a little annoying).

[b] Completed the game: [/b]
   As expected, I beat a game from my childhood that isn't as amazing as it used to be. A very strangely made remaster. Updated textures and shadows were added only to certain elements (vegetation, ground, water, rocks, lighting and costume), and everything else was forgotten. And it looks strange when there is a cool detailed costume on which shadows and lighting play, and the face of the Prophet or Psycho is the same as in the original (was it really difficult to add details). For my personal taste, the picture is also very oversaturated and the atmosphere of some locations is lost. Everything else is the same as before.

[b] Verdict: [/b]
   A remaster of a game that many wanted but ended up underwhelming. I would advise you to play the 2007 version (if you can find it) and experience more sensations from childhood, and modern builds will already give more fps than before (I got 85 in 4K with a drop to 72 FPS). I expected more from this game, but unfortunately it disappointed me. So I cannot advise an ordinary person (not familiar with the series) to buy it, and to an ardent fan of the original I can only say that it is at your own peril and risk.

If you got here, then know that you are the BEST!!!

TLDR: 
Yet another "remaster" that has enshittified a beloved classic and neutered it. If you REAAAALLY want this, try and wait for 90% off sale. Otherwise avoid it. 
If you want a truly remastered(ish) Crysis, I would suggest firing up original one with Tactical Expansion Mod, awailable here: https://www.moddb.com/mods/tactical-expansion-mod
For optimizing original to run on newer hardware, refer to PC Gaming Wiki here: https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Crysis


Pros: 
Newer CryEngine (3, I think) gives you better graphics, and nominally better optimizations: but I haven't seen much difference between original's maxed out and Remaster's High setting graphics.
Onslaught Level gives you as initial spawn tank with infinite main cannon ammo, unlike original where it was limited to 25-30 shells, if I remember correctly.
Achivements, maybe, due to most of them being tied to story progression, with only about 5 or 6 referring to various gameplay and physics shenanigans. And most of those are achiveable on first playtrough. For Achievement hunters, do not expect to sweat too much if you want to get them all.

Cons: 
EVERYTHING ELSE.  
Mods? Fukken gone.
Multiplayer? Fukken gone.
Warhead expansion pack/sidestory? DOUBLE fukken gone. Seriously, you only get first Crysis, and it is playable trough in 6-8 hours, I have about 8.5 hours of game time at writing this, and had made a playtrough on Medium while suffering from cold, so thus was not at 100%. 
Sound: some details are better, as well as audio cues about suit status being more prominent, but other are at same exact level as original.
AI: braindead idiots, with occasional wallhacking spots of "briliance". (I also play Star Citizen,game based on heavily modified Cryengine off-fork and even with SC's servers running badly, AI there is still miles better and more lethal that here.)
UI: worse. Older player may remember how you could choose between different colors for HUD and menus, and EVEYRTHING would be adjusted for color. Well, not in this remaster. Original's Olive Drab Green still remains strong in game and on menus.
I also noticed stutterings, mostly on Assault and Onslaught levels, ones that are massively sprawling and stretch for kilometers. SO, my guess is, the game has not been nearly as well optimized and it could have been. 

Closing: I only bought this because it was on 90% sale, and I still feel ripped off. Remaster that is more of a sloppily done port to newer hardware and OS rather than proper remaster. Think long and hard if you really would like to buy one.

[h1]The 100% Crysis Remastered Review[/h1]

[table]
[tr]
[td][b]Pros[/b][/td]
[td][b]Cons[/b][/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Graphical enhancements breathe new life into the classic[/td]
[td]VTOL mission pilot control issues on PC without a controller[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Innovative gameplay mechanics and suit powers[/td]
[td]Infested with bugs, notably sound issues and invisibility glitches[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Diverse and engaging combat scenarios[/td]
[td]Poor performance on systems that exceed the game's requirements[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]

[td][/td]

[td][/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h3][b]Conclusion:[/b][/h3]

Crysis Remastered brings the classic shooter into the modern era with significant graphical updates and support for the latest display technologies, including HDR. The game's innovative suit powers and diverse combat scenarios remain as engaging as ever, providing a gameplay experience that is both challenging and rewarding.

The remaster enhances the iconic storyline and setting, allowing both new and returning players to experience the game's narrative in a visually stunning manner. The addition of modern resolutions support ensures that Crysis Remastered looks its best on contemporary hardware.

However, the game's transition to the modern era is not without its flaws. Notably, the VTOL mission presents a significant challenge for PC players due to control issues when using a mouse, necessitating the use of a controller for an optimal experience. Additionally, the game suffers from a variety of bugs, including sound issues that detract from the immersive experience. Sound effects may get stuck or disappear entirely, and invisibility glitches can break the gameplay flow.

Performance-wise, Crysis Remastered demands more from systems than expected, considering the technological advancements in gaming hardware. Players with high-end PCs may find the game running poorly, even when other graphically intense games perform flawlessly on the same setup.

In conclusion, while Crysis Remastered successfully revives a beloved classic with stunning graphical enhancements and maintains the core gameplay elements that made the original game a landmark in the FPS genre, it is hampered by technical issues. These include control problems, bugs, and unexpected performance requirements. Despite these setbacks, for fans of the series and newcomers alike, the game offers a worthwhile experience, albeit with some caveats.

I was forced to play this to run through Crysis again, as the GOG version no longer works on my PC, even with C1-Launcher. This game will boot on a modern rig, and that's the end of its advantages over the original. Gameplay is choppy and awkward (even moreso than C1), enemy AI oscillates between drool-crusted stupidity and supernatural feats of cognition, and some random element of the game will break every couple minutes. Maybe the audio cuts out and is replaced by a crackling noise, maybe the keybinds to switch weapons stop working so you have to flick the mouse wheel to make them function again, maybe an enemy gets flung into low orbit by a pile of wood planks, somehow alerting the other enemies to your presence. 
You get stuck on geometry constantly, and sometimes you're rendered totally unable to move. You go to load your quicksave, only to realize that you can't because manual saves have been removed entirely for no discernible reason. Every bug you encounter is exacerbated by the fact that if it persists, you have to go all the way back to a checkpoint. I quit after encountering a bug that broke the audio every time I died, and which lasted until I restarted the game. This is a shockingly bad "remaster" that demands you mod it just as much as you would have to mod the original to make it playable. You'll be asking "can my PC run Crysis?", but for all the wrong reasons.

Don't know how it compares to the original Crysis, but here's my thoughts.

Positives:
Looks absolutely astonishing, especially in the hyper-atmospheric and detailed alien structure levels.
Fairly small download size for such a good-looking game, and system requirements aren't too bad either. Turns out it can run Crysis!
Decision to stick to a relatively manageable and linear progression path in such a large play area, rather than go full-on open world, is to be applauded, so not much unnecessary busywork or meandering.
Gameplay is mixed up with armour and cloak abilities engineered into your nano-suit, letting you go stealthier if you want to, or help you out in seemingly impossible situations.

Negatives:
It's short. The end credits (which are interminable) feel longer than the game. For completionists, there's no excuse for that. 
I wasn't able to use the mouse to steer the vehicles, like I could with the Halo games. You may have to make do with arrow keys or get a controller.
Foliage, no matter how dense, does not seem to hide you from enemies well enough, and yet it's difficult to see them.
Feels slightly bland and generic at first, like a typical AAA shooter (but persevere with it and you should have fun). The unimaginative story doesn't help.

Overall, it's fine, not life-changing but entertaining enough while it lasts. I wonder how good the rest of the games in the series are.

[h1] Crysis Remastered: A Disappointing Encounter for the Nanosuited Warrior [/h1]

[b]Greetings, mere mortals.[/b]

It's I, Starscream, once again, to share my recent experience with Crysis Remastered on my new OLED TV. Previously, I extolled its virtues, but alas, after this recent encounter, my opinion has shifted.

The original game was akin to wearing a golden armor, reminiscent of my legendary exploits in the Transformers episode, The Golden Lagoon. However, what I've noticed in this remastered version are not upgrades but downgrades. The lack of plant physics is appalling. In the old game, you could interact with foliage, pushing plants aside as you moved through them. Now? You simply clip through them like a malfunctioning Decepticon.

And the nighttime, supposed to be an immersive experience with ray tracing, falls utterly short. Instead of darkness, the night is as bright as an energon cube, ruining the tension the original game offered. The flashlight no longer serves its purpose, leaving me disappointed and vexed, much like Megatron after a failed conquest.

[hr][/hr]

In conclusion, Crysis Remastered on my new OLED TV is a letdown. It's like encountering a malfunctioning Seeker in the midst of battle. The downgrades from the original, particularly in plant physics and the lack of darkness in the night, have soured the experience. I'd have to give this version a Starscream-revoked rating of [b]3/10[/b], purely due to these disappointing deviations from the original game's immersion and mechanics.

Crysis was my favorite video game franchise as a teenager, yet I was lukewarm at Crysis 1 for a few things – balance, level design and AI, but this remastered version turns out to be more likeable thanks to rebalance.

The original is not an easy game and the high-tech nanosuit always feels like it is no thicker than a piece of paper, especially for my younger self who was a much less experienced gamer. Some weapons are difficult to work with because of the range and recoil, and damage seems wildly inconsistent, like a helicopter could eat 3 shots of RPG like nothing.

With the rebalance in remaster, nonsense like that no longer happens and all weapons are more manageable and fun to use with consistent damage. Difficulty and playtime drop as a result (15 vs 7 hours for the first playthrough), but it is a major step up for the experience. On the flip side, the necessity of stealth largely decreases, and I find myself always in favor of direct combat with the game becoming easier, so I say the remaster is less strategic and more simple shooting fun, though higher difficulty should revert that.

Perhaps because of the rebalance and the lower difficulty, or the developer made some changes in levels (I am not sure if there are any), or just me became a better gamer, the remaster doesn’t have a lot of frustration the original has, which is why back then, I was not a fan of the more open level design of Crysis 1.

With the frustration gone, I started to appreciate the more open level design allowing more freedom to decide how to approach objectives. I also become appreciative of the level variety that has car, ship, tank and aircraft levels arranged in an organized manner like Halo, which the second and third Crysis no longer have. That said, it is still confusing AF on how to kill the first boss in the final level as the game still doesn’t give clear instructions.

It is disappointing that the remaster doesn’t fix the biggest issue - AI. They are still dumb AF and they still have hypersensitive detection as the original - the lush vegetation makes it difficult for players to spot enemies, but they have no trouble seeing through, reminding me why the OG is so frustrating.

The OG has great graphics for its time but is not comparable to modern games. The remaster updated but didn’t overhaul graphics, and what really noticeable changes are clearer water, bluer sky, greener vegetation and more saturated color tones, which make it less photorealistic than the original. While doing so, the game introduces a contrast issue causing dark areas to be very hard to see, but without offering a proper tool to calibrate.

In conclusion, the remaster indeed is a better version of the game, but I don’t think the improvements are substantial enough to warrant a re-release (an rebalance update to the OG is probably enough). It is more of an eye-grabber for Cry Engine and future sequel. But if you have the original, you can get the remaster dirt cheap now, so why not?

This review used to be a general review of Crysis, but I've decided to edit it in favor of a review of the differences between the 2007 game, and Remastered. First, let me get a big thing out of the way. This version is based on the Xbox 360/Playstation 3 port of Crysis. This was likely done as those ports were done on CryEngine 3, while the PC original runs on CryEngine 2. Unfortunately, this brings some sacrifices. The enemy placement and number in levels is different from the PC release. and the AI also behaves slightly differently. Certain visual features are missing or replaced with more performance-friendly and in some cases less impressive looking counterparts. The infamous "Ascension" mission was missing at launch, and was only added in a patch later down the line, and there's a widespread bug in that said mission that prevents mouse input, requiring use of a controller or a program to map mouse input to controller input. In terms of general visual quality and design, it's a real mixed bag. Some stuff looks really good like the overall lighting composition, water looks great, it's not a bad-looking game by any means, but then there's some iffy stuff. Most, if not all. of the geometry and meshes, are exactly the same. This means many objects are still very obviously jagged and low-detail. The colors in the Remaster are also far more saturated, most notably in the missions taking place in forests and jungles, the grass and leaves on the trees are a richer, brighter green, which gives the game a less photorealistic look. I definitely wish there was a mod that changed said foliage assets to a more natural hue. (This is more of a personal nitpick rather than an objective criticism, however) Performance and tech-wise this remaster is actually a pretty dramatic step up. Anti-Aliasing looks far better than the 2007 game's primitive MSAA solution, leading to far less flickering on stuff like foliage or distant detailed objects and textures. You can push out the game's rendering and draw-distance a lot more, at the incredibly demanding "Can it Run Crysis?" setting, the game's LOD and Foliage rendering are pushed out to the max level and every object is always rendered at full detail, no matter how far away it is. Unless you have a super-beefy PC this option isn't really practical and is mostly meant for future-proofing the game. In terms of performance, the remaster is just better than the original game. Just the fact that it partially takes advantage of multiple cores and threads is huge, and for anyone with an RTX card, DLSS is also an option, so you get much better performance at very near to native image quality, and sometimes even better. All-in-all, there's a lot that's been improved in this remastered version but there's also a lot that's disappointing. This means that there's no real ideal version of Crysis. If you go with the original you miss out on the improved performance, AA, and lighting. If you choose the Remaster you lose out on the arguably better artistic design in many areas and missing or worse-looking effects. Because of this I can't really give a recommendation on which is better. I played the Remaster first and had a great time but after also playing the original for a bit some of the features that version has are sorely missed in the Remaster. I'd say if you want the extra performance play this version, but if you have a really beefy CPU and don't mind some framerate dips then go for the 2007 original.

It is still staggering to believe that a game of this graphical calibre came out in 2007. From a visual perspective, Crysis at its best can still look better than many AA games coming out even today. For older gamers, it is worth getting just to actually be able to run it on max settings now (provided you have the hardware), for younger gamers, it is a look into the past and an opportunity to experience a technical feat firsthand.

This is not to say that Crysis is perfect though, far from it. While the story premise is reasonably interesting, there is barely any depth to it. Certain sections like the flying part, while ambitious, will definitely feel lacking now that one has the experience of controls in modern games. Some of the UX design is a bit questionable as well and the power-jump is just downright wonky.

That being said, it is still worth getting, at least when on sale.

Although I've said "Yes" to whether I would recommend it, this review should be taken as a criticism rather than praise towards the game. 

Let's start with some gameplay views: The nanosuit now functions a lot like the way it does in 2 and 3. Default is Strength mode and the suit regenerates energy only in this mode. Armor mode passively drains energy aside from taking hits. 

The good news is, this can all be reverted by heading to Options --> Game Settings --> check mark Classic Nanosuit. Suit shortcuts is also something you may want to look at, as enabling Classic Nanosuit mode makes you unable to use the toggle keys to quickly switch modes. A mixed bag, but my preference is using the Classic Nanosuit.

As for the rest of the game. Quite a few graphics glitches are noticeable in many environments. A.I. behavior is not as refined as before and can end up behaving very strangely at times, or stuck in a spot especially if you reload a checkpoint near a patrol.

One pain point for me is that the game does not play all the dialogues properly. Like the in the final part on the aircraft carrier and in the mines there are missing some dialogues. Technically they are there in the game but the game proceeds too quickly before they can play. Can be rectified somewhat with some xml edits but we shouldn't have had to.

Biggest owie for me is during the final fight on the carrier deck against the mothership. Very often one of two things or both will occur: 1. Psycho and Helena don't disable the shields even if all hostiles have been cleared, and this can happen for either of the "arm" shields. 2. The boss will be stuck continuously using its freezing beam for several minutes non-stop leaving you on a constant loop of being frozen, unfrozen and refrozen even on the easiest difficulty. Eitherways you have no choice but to reload the checkpoint.

So, if given a choice, I'd recommend you get the original Crysis from GOG which incorporates a fix for the executable.

I will say this much for the game though: the looks have definitely been touched up and a lot of places and objects are certainly more detailed and more beautiful. VFX also improved. But yes, buggy.

Its fun, yes. It was a milestone when it was initially released, and while its a super linear story shooter, it still manages to suck you in. A lot of the features of this engine was soon to be the standard in later released games.

However, strictly talking about the first Crysis Remastered Game, I cannot advise you to buy it.

What is the problem?

The Crysis 1 Remaster is based on the Xbox 360 Release Code, and therefore is heavily downgraded in a lot of areas. (e.g. Vegetation doesnt even react to your explosions anymore.)
It also just runs bad. Lets face it, its not a debate. The game has no noteworthy upgrades besides a very basic raytracing implementation and some lighting upgrades. Playing the original game heavily modded with similar upgrades, is still running - twice - as good as this remaster. How can such an old game only run on 70 fps on a modern mid-end machine? (RTX 3080, 5600x) I used to play the original game on a 7800 GT with an Athlon XP 3200+, just think about this for a moment. Im not even talking about the "Can it run Crysis?"-Meme Graphic-Mode, that has practically no noteworthy difference then just running the game in a slideshow.

While not so important for me personally, as I dont think a lot of people would still play it today, its also missing the multiplayer part of the original game. Something that should be mentioned.

It also doesnt come with the standalone addon Crysis Warhead, and there is also no Remaster-Version in general for Crysis Warhead. Something I think is needed, considering the price-tag for this remaster.

So as long as you are not buying it for the integrated nanosuit-hotkey mode (Introduced in Crysis 2 and 3), or the achievements, you are better off with the original game. You can get the original game on origin for like 2 dollars, or on GOG for like 5 dollars. Also buy the original Crysis Warhead.

Only ever buy this remaster when the whole Trilogy is heavily discounted and you already know you want to play the sequels.

Crysis works well for me because it's got a lovely outdoor setting, not claustrophobic at all so far. It's also got an easy mode for people who love to murder but aren't very good at it. I still die, but not that much... There are four difficulty settings, so for you people out there with skills, I'm sure you'd find the more difficult settings fun.

If you're looking for a super complex game, this probably isn't it. I just get my missions and keep moving through them with stealth or force or both. 

MAJOR CON:

I play the Crysis games twice per year and I have enjoyed them for many years.

I didn't like the combat, the AI, the level design, the boss fights, the gimmick boss, the weapons, the plot, the dialogues; just played for the lore. You don't see enemies, whereas they see you from a tiny speck of line of sight while you're in bushes. Shooting enemies feels nothing; just nothing; absolute zero. They just lie down, then you know they're dead. 

Some of the weapons are useless. I didn't find any Scar ammo until the end of the game, yet it was useless then. I had to use FY71; it was alright, as you find plenty of ammo. Oh man, its accuracy... It is horrible at long distances. Shotgun is OK. Never used any grenades or never used them effectively. SMG was immensely OP than I thought it would be. 

The level design is repetitive, boring, and limited. I see a missed chance to be a game that has a good stealth side.

Also, I would expect a character that has a nano suit can slide and jump further while sprinting--you can do it partially, yet the movement is horrible. 

The only intriguing thing is the lore, the machines, the Ceph that have arrived in and lived on earth millions of years by now; just as in the AC series, Crytek puts in front of us a sci-fi lore that arouses excitement, an unworldly civilization living before and during human civilization.

Crysis created a benchmark in terms of Video games graphics which is still relevant today. Replaying this game after so many years brings back a lot of memories. Of course there are noticeable minor glitches, but that doesn't hinder playing it.

The remastered version of Crysis 1 does add a lot of new graphical flair compared to the old one. The only reason while it might sometimes feels 'still old' is because they did not reworked the 3D models with more polygons as far as I can tell. But effects and new features are added, more world objects, distance is more clear and complex, and also the game engine can handle now higher FPS more fluently than the classic version.

[b]What I did like?[/b]

* more detailed world on distances
* added Raytracing, DLSS and HDR support
* whole engine was tweaked to provide better effects
* high FPS does look now fluent (old version had issues)
* changed suit control like Crysis 2+3 (classic behaviour is still an option)
* the story is still awesome and the nanosuit does make so much fun to use

[b]What did I hate?[/b]

This game is definitelly just optimized for Nvidia GPUs. AMD users like me get a little bit left behind, unfortunetally, even with strong AMD cards. 

For example on startup, the game complains about and old driver version (Nvidia) and cannot provide DLSS due to this. That is fine, as my AMD RX 7900 XTX cannot handle DLSS anyway ;)

Also some unpleasant graphic glitches do appear, especially related to the sky. HDR messes up with clouds while camera is moving (if HDR is deactivated all is fine, so I suggest to use the Windows auto-HDR option, it handles the game much better), also the stars during night do flicker in artefacts (there is a third-party-tool fix for this), and during night on some areas the adaptive brightness goes crazy. Luckily most game levels were fine.

But what really killed it for me is that this game does NOT contain the addon Crysis:Warhead, which tells the story about Psycho in a parallel timeline during the second half of the game. It is an important and awesome part of the whole Crysis story too. Sad that new players won't experience this unless they buy and play the old standalone version.

[b]Summary:[/b]

Still, the story and the game series is awesome and beside all of the negative things fun to play. If you have a Nvidia GPU, or a stronger AMD GPU which can handle the remastered version you should definitely still go for it and not the classic version if you are interested. But I am still disappointed that the devs made so obvious mistakes. If they going to fix the key critics, I will glady change my review. But I doubt that this will happen.

This game was once the benchmark for rig capabilities, while I beat the original back in the day I did not remember much of it. So I’ll base this review off the remastered version. 

Pro’s: 
• Visually the game is still pretty decent, obviously it’s not anywhere near today’s AAA titles. Graphically it’s somewhere in between a PS4/PS5.

• It plays well on deck but it does drain your battery. I get about 2 hours of gameplay on a full charge. 

• It’s a good before bed game, it doesn’t require much thought and you can unwind while playing it. 

Cons:

• Cloaking doesn’t seem to be as effective as it once was, it seems to randomly not work. 

• Ammo for the SCAR is scarce so you spend the majority of the game using whatever crap you find on the ground. 

• Enemies seem to materialize out of no where, while this can make the game entertaining after awhile you end up running by them to avoid the repetitive BS. 

Conclusion: I see a lot of people complaining about hit markers and TTK on enemies. This is not COD and the game was from a different era. It’s somewhat of a cross between Soldier of Fortune and DOOM. It was experimental at the time with a lot going on (with the nano suit) compared to typical FPS at the time. It’s a good game if you remember what it is.. is it worth 30$??? Not really, then again if it keeps me entertained for more than 10 minutes it’s better than most 60$ games. 

TLDR: If you played the OG crysis give this a shot, if you just got your drivers license in the last 10 years don’t bother.

[b] Graphics : 6/10 [/b]

The game is OKish in 2023, but honestly, you don't need this remaster. The modded 2007 original version will do better, with lot more possibilities (textures, Time of day, lightning, effects, etc).

This is, without a doubt, the most busted game I have played this year, and easily one of the most busted that I’ve ever played. Here’s just some of the issues that I experienced:

- Some of the worst human enemy AI I have ever seen. Sometimes they spot you easily from a long distance, other times they fail to spot you when you’re cloaked right next to them. Sometimes they struggle to hit you up close, other times they hit you perfectly from 50 metres away. But most of the time, they’re just insanely dumb, failing to use any sort of realistic tactics or behaviour to take me down. They only posed somewhat of a challenge on the hardest difficulty because a few of them could kill me in less than a second.

- Blatantly unfinished sound mixing. Sometimes the guns would fire very loudly, other times I could barely hear them. Music just didn’t play during certain scenes, and sometimes after alt-tabbing, it would return whilst blasting over the rest of the mix, making all the human voices nearly inaudible. 

- Frequent, immersion-breaking animation glitches and physics ragdolls. One enemy vaulted over a barrier that just wasn’t there, many NPCs walked into walls and objects when they should have gone around them, and multiple character ragdolls got stuck halfway through the floor. A few of these are fine, but I’ve seen more of them in this game than I’ve experienced in the 70 or so hours I’ve put into Starfield so far, and that’s a Bethesda game.

- Inexplicable frame drops within areas where no frames should be dropping. Apparently, a gigantic battle can maintain 60fps perfectly fine, but quieter parts of the game where there is far less going on? Tanked straight down to 30fps. 

- Every boss fight was completely laughable. The first one, a human general, ended up crouch walking away from me the entire fight. I’d unload two mags into him, he’d disappear then reappear someone else, then he’d return to crouch walk away from me again. Did this three times and he was dead. Not a single shot was fired at me, ruining what was meant to be the most critical moment of the game up to that point. And in terms of the large alien robots, while they weren’t inherently broken, they were just lame. The massive spider-looking one had no weakpoints, so I just unloaded a thousand bullets and rockets into it until it died. The mothership only had weakpoints, and they were all available at the start so there were no attacks to dodge or tasks to complete before they became exposed. Both bosses can kill you near instantly, so instead of being able to use that really cool suit the game gave you, you’re stuck to popping in and out of cover until they blow up, nothing special about it at all.

Maybe this is just a messed-up remaster, maybe this is how the game always was. All I know is that my first proper experience with this franchise was verging on complete disaster in terms of its technical competency. Yes, the shooting is fun, I enjoyed using the suit abilities, and the early level design is really great. But all of these elements were marred by consistent annoyances that either took me out of the experience or ruined parts of it entirely. You know those videos of games like Aliens Colonial Marines and Fallout 76 that showcase the funniest, most buggy parts of the experience to the world? What you see in those videos is close to what I experienced in Crysis Remastered. Why does it matter if I can run Crysis, if the game I’m trying to run just isn’t an enjoyable experience?

This is made even worse by the fact that these developers had a year to fix the game up on the EGS before it was released on Steam, but it’s evidently been hardly patched since that original release. Furthermore, this is a pretty short game, taking no more than 6-8 hours to 100% the entire thing, so the fact that there are this many issues, in what should be a super streamlined experience, is pretty ridiculous. And let’s not forget that this remaster was based on the console versions instead of the iconic PC version for some reason, alongside the omission of the multiplayer mode and the Warhead expansion.

Somehow, this game has a mostly positive reception on Steam, so maybe you will be luckier than I was. Unfortunately, I can only speak from my experience, and all I’ll say is that I’m happy this torture was over relatively quickly. Fingers crossed that the remasters of 2 and 3 aren’t as completely broken as this game was for me.

[b][u]This review switched from a "recommendation" to "not recommended". [/u][/b]
I bought the "Crysis-Remaster Edition" together with "Hunt Showdown" for roundabout 30€(~34,92USD). 
I played through the whole game on "Delta" (Highest Difficulty). I played it for ~10H in 3 sessions.
[b][u]Controls:[/u][/b]
[b]1)Nanosuit[/b]
By default, you get a suit more similar to "Crysis 2". An easier to control suit with less versatility. It is perfect for console players, but if you're using a mouse and Keyboard i highly recommend switching to the more versatile "Classic" Nanosuit.
Options -> Game options Tick "Classic Nanosuit"(Don't forget to Click Apply, if you just press ESC afterwards your changes will not be applied)
For newcomers having problems with the Classic suit just remember:
M3+Mouse Forward = Speed (A movement as if you would engage)
M3+Mouse Backward = Cloak (A movements as if you would retreat)
M3+Mouse Right = Strength (Imagine a Knight, Sword in the Right hand)
M3+Mouse Left = Armor (Imagine a Knight, Shield in the Left hand)
[b]2)PC Controls[/b]
The default controls of the remastered edition could be described as very "Creative".
Like Putting lean left and right on T and H or changing fire mode on 5.
I highly recommend changing the controls to something similar to the original.
I use the Classic nanosuit with these control changes:
Q/E - Lean left/right
H - Change Grenade
C - Fire Mode (I put it on C instead of X because i have big hands)
X  - Customization Menu
STRG - Crouch
T - Melee(Certain Objects like toilet brushes can be used as melee weapons.)
[b]3)Change Grenade bug[/b]
If you change your Grenade through the Grenade-Selection-Window and left click, you will throw the selected grenade;  in my case a smoke. Afterwards the grenade display in the HUD changed from frags to smokes. Up to this point everything is working as intended.
The smoke grenades were still displayed as the "active" grenade in my HUD. I was quite surprised when I intended to throw a smoke under myself to cover my retreat, but got blasted into space instead. It does not matter which grenade you have selected, if you press G and are in possession of a frag, a frag will be thrown.
[b]4)Hold Key[/b]
For some things you have to hold the key, just pressing it wont work. I repeatedly pressed F like a madman until I realized that I had to hold F to exchange my SCAR for a Shotgun.
[b]5)Automatic Gunlock[/b]
If you aim at a person who is on your side, you get a red X and your gun won't fire. This includes dead friendlies. The "Gunlock" hitbox is bigger than the actual hitbox of the entity. If you sit manually on a friendly tank you cannot openfire since you are sitting inside the gunlock-box. On the Aircraft Carrier I often could not shoot at the enemy, because my dead teammates were triggering the "Gunlock" making the end boss fight very frustrating.Ohh the Alien Trooper is right in front of you tearing through your HP? Sorry, I can't let you attack it because somewhere in that direction is a dead body that theoretically could get hit. Oops, you're dead. Thanks game!
[b][u]Artificial Intelligence:[/u][/b]
[b]1)AI Detection[/b]
The AI in general seems to be more perceptive, you are no longer a ghost when activating "Cloak" mid combat. Also even when invisible the AI will notice you when you get too close; I noticed that the hard way when I tried to sneak past an ATV (Jeep) and the gunner unloaded his MG right into my face.
The only annoying part is that they seem to "Lock On" and sometimes see through brush. Once they are (Red)alerted to your presence they do not care how many bushes, trees, fences, etc. are between you and them, they'll shoot at you with pinpoint accuracy. On the other hand, if they're still yellow, they are sometimes stupidly blind.
[b]2)AI Navigation[/b]
If I recall correctly, the AI navigation inside the Cryengine is mostly done with "Forbidden Area" and "Navigation Area". The First one just prevents the AI from stepping inside the zone, the second is made for precise Navigation, where the AI can only move from and to placed navigation points and can only enter and leave the zone through placed entry markers. The Navigation Area appears to be not working. The AI is walking against walls, gets stuck in buildings.
[b]3)SmartAI Objects[/b]
In the original Crysis game where invisible AI-behavior markers where the Enemy AI would perform certain actions like smoking or repairing something. Most of these Objects do not work. I noticed it when the guy who is usually relieving himself next to an explosive barrel was missing in the first level.
[b]4)AI Enable/Disable bugs[/b]
The "spawning" of enemy AI is done through Flowgraph. Something happens like entering an area and then an AI Entity is switched from Disable to Enable and it pops into the world.
This leads to some enemies standing around in a pose that looks like someone pulled the Plug. Like at the end of level 2 some of the patrolstaff stood on a rock, armes straight down, with their FY71 attached to their right hand, staring into the jungle.
 [b]5)AI Boats are less Aggressive[/b]
In the original the boats in the first level were spotting you quite fast. They may have been a bit annoying but they were definitely a threat. The Boats in the remake are no longer the Hawks of the original, instead they are completely blind. In the 1st Level, I killed the first boat's gunner from the Jammer position and destroyed the second boat with the MG of an ATV(Jeep) from a beach near the KVA Command Post. In both cases the Boats did NOT return fire.
[b]6)CQC Tank[/b]
The battle tanks in the 5th map only fight back if you drive close to them, a few foot soldiers of that map just run past the player, not even attacking when you shoot at them.
[b]7)No Helicopter PTSD[/b]
In the original I remember a surge of helicopters getting in my way. There were so many of them that they were absolutely annoying. But in the remaster, there were only a few of them, I'm not sure if they were removed or the AI just couldn't find their way anymore.
[b]8)Alien AI[/b]
The Alien Scouts(Flying Tentacle Monster) didn't use their Secondary attack even once(Charge Attack, firing an explosive projectile). The Alien Troopers(The little jumpy ones) had trouble moving in the Aircraft Carrier, sometimes being unable to attack.
[b][u]Damage:[/u][/b]
[b]1)Object Damage Nerf[/b]
I might be wrong, but the damage dealt by throwing objects seems to have been nerfed. This is a good thing. One Shotting the NVA-General with a Box was kind of a balacebreaker.
[b]2)Suppression Fire[/b]
I don't remember if it was the same in the original but incoming fire comes with Camerashakes and other effects. It makes returning fire more difficult, I like that.

[b][u]Cosmetics:[/u][/b]
[b]1)Roads(Nitpick)[/b]In the Cryengine, The Roads are drawn with a Pathtool and then plastered onto the map like a decal. But it seems a few of them are floating.

[b][u]Conclusion:[/u][/b][b]I do not know in detail what was changed in the remaster. If I'm correct and my experience is not just a series of rare bugs happening one after another then the AI system has been impaired. Whatever they did jammed multiple "Tools" responsible for AI navigation.And if they wouldn't have made the AI more perceptive, this would have been more obvious from the start. I cannot recommend the remaster anymore, if you want to play Crysis, buy the original. Get it with it's "Standalone Expansion Hybrit" Crysis Warhead(You Play Psychos perspective), you 'll be happier with these two with lower (If you can say that about  a Crysis title) graphics, than with the remaster. If you're a console player.... only get it when it is on discount![/b]

I have to be honest, my heart has always leaned more towards "Crysis 2." Maybe it's the nostalgia of that urban battleground or the more polished feel. But that doesn't mean the original "Crysis" doesn't pack a punch.

Set in a lush, tropical paradise, the game is a beautiful mix of stealth and chaos. The suit's capabilities, switching between armor, speed, and stealth, are a game-changer (quite literally). Each encounter feels like a sandbox where strategies can be mixed and matched. And then there's that iconic tagline: "But can it run Crysis?" This game was, and still is, the benchmark for graphical prowess.

The remastered version? It does justice to the original, amplifying what was already a graphical marvel. The sun filtering through the dense foliage, the ripples in the water, the detailed textures — it's all enhanced and feels more alive.

For all its worth, while "Crysis 2" might have stolen my heart, the original "Crysis" laid the foundation. It set the stage for what was to come, introducing us to the Nanosuit, the alien threat, and a world where strategy and raw firepower go hand in hand.

So, if you're curious about the Crysis universe and wondering where to start, "Crysis Remastered" is the gateway. It's the genesis of the series, and it provides context to the sequels. While it might not be my top pick of the franchise, it's undeniably essential. Strap on that Nanosuit and dive in; the jungle awaits.

This short review is less about Crysis, the game itself, and more about the lack of effort put into this "remaster." 
The original game had its fair share of glitches and nothing was done here to fix them. AI pathing issues like enemies moving back and forth against walls/objects, animation issues like helicopters turning sideways without animation and zipping into a wall and exploding, etc. just stupid things you can laugh at, They aren't as bad during the majority of the game since the way the levels are structured are semi-open with your main objectives being having to interact with/destroy an object, or reach a marker, which means stupid AI behavior can be ignored. However, during the final quarter the game decides to become more cinematic and turns into a linear scripted shooter with aliens where you have to follow npcs, clear waves of enemies or wait for scripted sequences to play out. The game completely falls apart here. Enemies will fall over dead with their AI deactivated when their hp reaches zero, but their full death animations won't play out so they won't register as killed by the game, forcing a checkpoint restart if you're lucky, or having to fully quit and restart the game, or, in the worst case scenario, a full level restart. The final level is especially bad at this, with bugs where the sort-of final boss straight up won't spawn once you reach the end, requiring a full level restart and hoping it fixes itself, or, upon beating it and waiting for the real final boss to show up, hoping a scripted event that leads up to it actually playing correctly and not ending up with the npcs not responding, in which case no amount of checkpoint restarts will fix it, so the level has to be completely restarted and you'll have to hope it fixes itself. 
These issues were present in the original release and no attempt was made to fix them here (there's other minor but annoying issues still present too, e.g. vegetation counting as an object so the main character will place c4 on a bush in mid-air instead of throwing it and not being able to pick it back up). This extends to the rest of the remastered trilogy, but the first Crysis is easily the worst and most prone to game ending issues compared to the sequels. 

The game itself is decent, though even back in the day it went downhill once you stop fighting human enemies due to the change in game structure from semi-open levels to a linear cinematic shooter like I said before. And even then there's some parts during its better levels where it gets kind of annoying to play, such as some pointlessly big barren areas where most of your time is spent sprinting from one place to another. This is one of those things where the sequels are way better despite being more cramped due to their console-focused design. 

In short, get this discounted and, once you reach the final few levels, watch the cutscenes and ending on Youtube. Or don't, since the rest of the franchise never directly follows up on this games ending and it was solved in a tie in comic.

Released in 2014, this review of Crysis Remastered takes into account the criteria and standards of that era.

(̿▀̿ ̿Ĺ̯̿̿▀̿ ̿)̄ 👍

TLDR: Crysis Remastered impresses with breathtaking visuals and retains the beloved game play mechanics of the original. However, the game is marred by occasional bugs and glitches, while the traversal system and final map could use further polishing. AI improvements are also desired. Despite its flaws, Crysis Remastered offers an immersive experience for fans seeking nostalgia.

With all the said.. Still recommend.

Pros:

Breathtaking Visuals : Crysis Remastered stuns with its meticulously redesigned environments, impressive lighting effects, and attention to detail. The game takes full advantage of modern hardware capabilities, creating a visually immersive experience.

Refined Game play Mechanics: The remastered edition retains the beloved core gameplay mechanics, such as the versatile Nanosuit and open-ended level design. Players have the freedom to approach combat in various ways, adding depth to the game play experience.

Engaging Nostalgia: Crysis Remastered successfully captures the essence of the original game, offering a nostalgic journey that fans will appreciate. The updated visuals and refined controls breathe new life into the classic game play.

Cons:

Bugs/Glitches: Crysis Remastered is not without its share of bugs and glitches, as has been commented on by many players. While my play through was relatively smooth, I did encounter one level-breaking bug that forced me to restart the final level.

Polishing Travel Mechanics: The traversal system in Crysis Remastered could benefit from further polishing. Walking across terrain feels less smooth than expected, with abrupt level changes that disrupt the fluidity of sprinting.

Frustrating Final Map: The final map proves to be a source of frustration. Navigating through small hallways and doors is acceptable, but encountering issues with passing through NPCs or NPC bodies necessitates reloading checkpoints to progress.

AI Improvements Needed: Although the AI has been enhanced, some players may find that it could have been further improved in terms of enemy behaviour and tactical decision-making.

Conclusion:
Despite its captivating visuals and enjoyable game play, Crysis Remastered falls short in a few areas. The presence of bugs and glitches, although not pervasive, can disrupt the overall experience. Additionally, improvements are needed in the game's travel mechanics to ensure smoother movement and eliminate abrupt level changes. Lastly, the frustrating aspects of the final map, particularly the issues with interacting with NPCs, can hamper immersion and progress.

The graphics are ridiculously good for it's time -- and the small features like vegetation toppling over, buildings exploding in gameplay, and picking up wildlife really are impressive for a game nearing 2 decades old. Lots of vehicles to control, AA turrets, and a super badass suit with cloaking, fast running, high jump, and an armored mode. Weapons can be mildly upgraded with attachments. A bit of stealth, lots and lots of action, some cool moments and a whole lot of cheesy ones. The korean island setting is pretty cool with super open areas despite the game being linear -- you can tackle things in different ways. 

It's pretty janky here n there -- I didn't experience much jank until later on in the game. Dialogue can get cut off, AI can get pretty stupid, I see the potential for getting stuck in props, etc. 

The general gameplay and setting are definitely the shining parts of this game. Everything else wasn't too good to me (some of the characters -- mostly your commanders and other nanosuit friends I found enjoyable). Regardless it got me interested in the series and I'm looking forward to Warhead, 2, and 3.

The first half of the game is fun. You face a small army and feel powerful. The gun play is solid, the scenery is beautiful, and you have a variety of tools to get the job done. It's a bit glitchy but if I played this in 2007 it would have blown me away.

Once you defeat General Kyong, consider the game over. Congratulations, you beat a solid shooter. What follows is the biggest drop off in quality I think I've ever witnessed in a video game.

The next enemies are not fun to fight, the levels become really annoying to navigate and there's even an escort part. 

The real affront though is the final boss. It has attacks that you can do nothing about. Sometimes waves that you need to clear won't appear. Sometimes the game will crash.....Sometimes the final gun that you get just won't work.

Imagine getting the BFG in Doom or the Spartan laser in Halo for the first time and it just not firing...

After finally beating the boss, the game abruptly ends without the job being done.

A real shame for a game that had a lot of potential.

[b]:l[/b]

This is not [i]Crysis Remastered[/i] but [i]Ray Tracing: Crysis,[/i] with slapped on a 30 paper while it should have just been a free update, or a 5 paper DLC.

I get supporting Crytek in hope they'll pull out something good again, but this is simply overpriced; if only the owners of the old versions would have received this for free, I could understand the pricing, but as it stands, I don't.

Let me preface this by saying That Crysis is a very special game to me. No lie I've probably played this campaign about 25 times. Back in the day when I built my first computer with the phenom 9950 and a GTS 250 I was looking at benchmarks and I discovered this game. I got the demo and played it so many times. Then I got the game, and I loved every part of it: the human conflict, the aliens, the story, everything. Original Crysis wasn't the most optimized game out there and I saw a cry engine showcase with a part that looks just like the island from the first mission of the game then I heard a remaster was inbound, so I was expecting the quality from that showcase to be the entire game and boy was I wrong.

I'll start at the beginning. Crytek sold their souls to the devil and released Crysis remastered on the piece of shit epic game store as an exclusive for an entire year. I know they are starving for money, but this still stings. Anyways about a year later I got the entire trilogy for 70% off and today, I finally got around to playing it.

Some minor Spoilers I guess…..

And man, this game has issues. From visual minor to severe visual glitches that never existed in the first game to mechanics changes such as in that boss fight against that one guy in the nanosuit when you hit him, he has an EMP blast that completely stuns you and you can't do anything when you're stunned, that was not in the original game nor a feature of the nanosuit. That part made me mad as hell lol. That was a big change instead of a 1 vs 1 duel to the death everything is slowed down massively because you can no longer attack him immediately you have to run around and hunt for a weapon and then attack him while the doctor keeps yelling stop him the whole time which she says a lot due to how drawn out this fight is now and he seems to be made of titanium because he's a super bullet sponge now even just in strength mode.

Other changes include at the end when the big Ceph Walker thing grabs you can no longer face it to attack it to go free you're just kind of screwed if you get thrown too far and you die.

Also, when you're on the vehicle turret even if you turn off hold mouse to aim down sights you still must hold mouse to aim down the side of the turret it's quite stupid.

Regarding all these mechanical changes: a remaster is supposed to preserve everything, just improve visuals and optimizations and not reinvent the wheel by changing gameplay mechanics.

One surprising thing is this game preserved the VTOL mission which honestly, I was not expecting because that was cut from the original game that this is based off which is the Crysis version released for the PS3 and Xbox 360 so in short, we're basically playing a port of a PS3 and Xbox 360 game with some extra additional things bolted on.

This remaster was probably the most important remaster to me, and they fucked it up which is well known at this point. The only thing honestly that was improved was the 8K textures they used for the game, but you can fix that by playing the original with just a HD texture pack and done. Also, I was able to play the game from start to finish without a single crash so that's also a positive because their original game if you play about three missions straight, you're going to crash it's weird. 

There are all kinds of other examples of visual downgrades but a few I can think of is 1) at the starting of the first mission prophets face in the first mission intro had a lot more detail in the original. in the “Remake/Remaster” all the detail his face is just flat and 2) per object motion blur being completely removed that's something else you can see at the intro to the first level. 

This reviews all over the place, but I had to write what I'm feeling right after I finished it. I'm going to uninstall this crap and stick with the original which is far better. They shoehorned in cry engine 3 or whatever version they're using into this game, and it shows. This port/half assed remaster is trash I'm very disappointed. This is also much harder to run, and I don't see much visually to warrant that. The difference between Ray tracing on and off is next to none.

TLDR:  Sadly, I cannot recommend this at all. What I can recommend is that you go either on EA Origin or GOG and get the original Crysis and Crysis warhead they are both amazing open ended sandbox games.

So first of all - the performance. It's crap. On a pretty decent machine (5800X + 7900XT + 32GB RAM 3600 CL14) I get frame drops below 60 at 1440p... I'm sorry but the game does not look that good for this level of performance. The 7900XT is currently the 4th best GPU out there and yet it struggles with such an old game ? BS. Before anyone asks, RT was off.

Then there are the bugs, which mind you, were not present in the og version:
- The AI bugs out quite a lot. I've had situations where the bigger squid aliens would go limp and fall from the sky after killing them rather than triggering a death animation they should go through. They would also not explode, just stay there on the ground. Now this caused me to have to restart a few checkpoints cause their mere existence on the map would cause some mission objectives to not register as completed - fun.
- AI pathing is borked. There were so many times where the AI would have trouble either getting over terrain or even deciding where it wants to go, with characters sometimes spining around on their axis for a second before finally going in a given direction.
- World traversal is borked. I had many problems walking over some minor obstacles. This was especially egregious during the last mission where I hade trouble sometimes going through open doors/hatches because there was an alien lying in the doorway, wtf ?
- The audio is borked. Some sounds wouldn't play. Audio positioning is also crap. Many guns sound flat, hollow instead of impactful and punchy.
- Who the F is responsible for F'ing up mouse control in this game ?! I had to set the mouse speed slider to the absolute minimum and then set my mouse at 300dpi in my drivers to be able to play normally. Now this would work while on foot, however once I got into a tank, I had to speed up my mouse considerably to be able to move the turret in a effective way. And then, when I got inside the VTOL ? I had to put the slider to the middle otherwise the VTOL wouldn't even register any mouse movements at all... How ? Why ? There was no such issue in the OG version ! Why did you F this up ?

Avoid this remaster. It's not worth your time or your money, even on sale.

The first Crysis remaster is a bit spotty and deviates more towards “looking pretty” than it does “looking realistic” and removed things like manual saving. It's a mostly-better version of the original, but it's not a 1:1 comparison due to certain physics and shading features breaking in the Remaster, like vegetation reacting to explosives, or SVOGI drastically changing the Cutscenes in a decidedly worse way at times. Overall though? It's a smoother package, more widely accessible, and the RT is damn good.

I would personally recommend this remaster. I think it's overall, especially with the fan patch, a solid experience that runs well, looks pretty nice, and has friendlier balancing and pacing, and who doesn’t love screwing with Koreans?

The modern nanosuit controls are more intuitive to a lot of players, and the game's AI isn't as aim-bot-like anymore. And unless you're really familiar with Crysis, a number of the bugs won't be noticable.

If you don't enjoy this Crysis 1 remaster though, don't let that dissuade you from trying Crysis 2. Crysis 1 is an interesting game, and well worth playing, but it's kind of a mess, and it's not uncommon for newcomers to be like, "It has interesting ideas, but I don't see what the fuss is about."

While it feels and plays good its not well optimized.

With a 3080 TI and a 5900X on all high I get 60 FPS average. There are wild fluctuations as well as sometimes and especially indoors its 100 or 120 or you look at another part of the level and it goes super high. I had to tune it all down to high settings and disable RTX to have a stable framerate that isn't all over the place.

Crazy thing is also that it hardly makes a difference if I go for the highest settings or not performance-wise which leads me to the conclusion that it lacks optimization and makes me feel like I might have a better experience with the original modded.

It was also part of the Crytek bundle and pretty cheap for that. The old content is even worse though with the friendly AI getting stuck constantly and not helping you at all.

Also on a sidenote, one EXTREMELY annoying thing to me is the suit audio being absolutely annoying and there is no way to turn it off. Im not talking about the voice but the audio from it whenever you do stuff.

Hit sounds in general are EXTREMELY loud. If I hit an enemy its loud as if the shot that penetrated his body literally just entered my ear - WHY? The sound design does so much right - guns feel meaty and heavy, the soundtrack is great >like back then< but this stupid and plain retarded feedback from your shots and suit that you cant take off? UGH. The sound is actually very buggy, in some missions like in the alien structure there are spots where my gunshots are 2x as loud for no reason at all. Something is seriously wrong with this "remaster"

Its also extremely pathetic to remaster a console peasant version in that you cannot even save your game whenever YOU want to but some shitty checkpoint system from 15 years ago decides it. BLEH, but I knew what I was getting into so I was not surprised.

Oh and did you know that in a 2022 game YOU CANNOT CHANGE FOV WHICH IS A DEFAULT BASIC FEATURE SINCE...2010? Probably earlier? 60 FOV only for modern gamers I guess. Imagine implementing RTX but literally having no game designer in the team while you never played Crysis yourself -> this dev team.

TL:DR - Crysis that has its remastered moments with a huge grain of salt. "Fun but annoying" is how I feel about it. LOTS of issues with sound and nothing has been done to improve on old problems. Still finished it, fun at times and enough to not make me throw it away. Good game, poor remaster. Lots of bugs.

Extra note: You can change the fov my creating a txt file in your main folder and renaming it into a cfg with certain command lines.

However playing the game at 95 FOV makes you see through some stuff if you lean near walls. JUST WOW WHAT DID THEY REMASTERED? WTF, 95 FOV is an absolute standard FOV for FHD or 2K screens. Literally every shooter since a few years or more have a normal FOV of 85 or 95.

But no this game is only comfy...with 60...wtf

Important Edit: Final boss/part is EXTREMELY buggy. You can die from invisible fire and the boss sometimes just dont take damage while the game tells you to use your special launcher, you only damage it if you go infront of it directly for no logical reason at all. Also if you go infront you die from invisible flames that magically kill you in 4 ticks (1 second each). Extremely annoying ending. Its shit like this that keeps making this game feel so bad

This game may have been great for its time, but it doesn't seem to hold up too well in the modern day.
Personally, I would recommend starting with Crysis 2 if you are interested in the series and if you want to know about the story, either look up a playthrough or spend an hour on the wiki reading up on the story.

My reasons for this conclusion:
 - [b]The game's campaign is relatively short[/b] (it took me a bit under 8 hours to beat)
 - [b]The finer story elements feel disjointed, forced and random[/b]. There were quite a few times where I was looking at a situation and asking myself, "Why, why would you do that?!" or "How did I get here again?"
 - [b]The story feels... incomplete?[/b] The game ends rather suddenly and at a weird time with no true resolution to the plot. To further add to the confusion, when moving onto the next game, it is as if the characters of this game (Nomad, The doctor, Psycho) never existed
 - [b]Bad / unenjoyable boss fights.[/b] At the start of each boss fight, I found myself thinking, "Is this a boss fight? Why are we fighting? What just happened to 'x'?". And the fights themselves were of the type where you didn't know what was actually going on and after shooting at the boss a bunch you start wondering if there is a weak-spot or something that you need to hit to deal damage. A good example is the answer to the 2nd boss is to shoot it with ~4500 minigun rounds. (Because after shooting the boss with the first 1000 rounds and seeing nothing happen you are likely to consider shooting at it more with the same weapon). After every boss fight I just found myself thinking, [i]"Thank you! It is finally over!"[/i]
 - [b]Contradictory game play elements.[/b] This game if full of elements that directly contradict each other's purpose. A good example of this would be the stealth feature in the game, you are incentivised to use stealth in the game, problem being that enemies can frequently spot you at points where you still can barely make out the enemy with a 4x scope. Enemies spotting you is also instant or close to it. Additionally, if you fire when cloaked, your energy is instantly set to 0 (even with a suppressor) meaning you can only fire out of cloak (this does get addressed in later games) this also applies to all weapons, so a shotgun is just as valid as a pistol in terms of energy conservation. Human enemies also only die in 1 hit to headshots and can take 3+ hits to die to body shots. So, if you shoot and miss the head, you have alerted the entire enemy force to your presence. You also have your energy instantly get set to 0 if you get shot so using cloak so using it in a dangerous situation is likely to just leave you without energy and still in danger. All these factors made it so that it was far easier, less time consuming and less risky to just sprint past all the enemies you see
 - [b]Your character has surprisingly low durability.[/b] Despite wearing the most advanced suit of armor in the world, you still go down to a second of sustained fire from any weapon. Even if you use armor mode, it will only block maybe 4 bullets and leave you with no energy and no health
 - [b]Ceph are miserable to fight.[/b] There wasn't a second I fought the Ceph that I enjoyed. They are tanky, there is a lot of them, they are fast, and they can fly. I would find myself constantly looking into the sky wondering where I was being attacked from while being shot at from 3 different directions all while every enemy takes 2-3 shots from even the strongest weapons in the game. The only saving grace was that they dealt rather low damage. (again they are much more pleasant to fight in the later games)

In all, this game's primary effect on me was making me appreciate the other games more for their improvements to the formula

[h1]Crysis Remastered[/h1]
Crysis Remastered is a remaster of the iconic shooter by Crytek. In the latest version, only the quality of the graphics has changed, but as this is my first time with this series, I will review it from scratch.
[h1]The Plot[/h1]
We play as Nomad, a super-soldier who, together with his unit, goes on a mission to the Lingshan Islands to investigate Korean activity, which ends up in a fight for survival against very aggressive aliens. In general, this game can be compared to typical American action/sci-fi movies from the early 2000s. It is a shooter where we do not need to use too much brain power, but the characters that accompany us, the main character and the opponents are interesting enough to generate specific feelings for them. and opinions. Overall, I found the game-pacing to be very good here, the alien discovery intrigue and the final alien encounters are well separated from each other, creating tension and making the encounters more meaningful. All in all, each character has something to add here, and they have their own experiences and motivations, most of them aren't useless so even though we're a powerfull super-soldier, we don't feel like we have to do everything completely on our own.
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The mechanics of being a super soldier are great. We can run very fast, modify our weapons, and our super-strength and durability allow us to break through buildings and massacre opponents in melee combat. Speaking of buildings, I like that the environment, i.e. structures and trees, are mostly destructible, so the environments are very interactive, which is a lot of fun to just smash and blow things up. The shooting itself is good, some enemies are damage sponges, but overall it's good. The island itself is surprisingly huge, and while it's mostly jungle, the massiveness of the map is admirable. Moving on to the aliens, I really liked them, although they follow the same logic as all the aliens from early 2000s and late 90s movies. Anyway, the game tries to make them original enough. The skirmishes with them are very dynamic, we often fight side by side with normal soldiers, and we fight for survival in very explosive skirmishes against an opponent that has much better technology, and some terraforming capabilities. Pure epicness and the last act of the island evacuation is brilliant. The only problem with all this is the part of the game where we enter the alien base, where gravity is turned off. The environment, although full of detail, is full of annoyingly fast enemies, it's hard to navigate, and the fact that we're constantly turning in place certainly didn't help my hungover stomach when going through this mission.
[h1]Technical Matters[/h1]
Graphically it's very good, but in the tradition of Crysis, the optimization is poor. At least the game doesn't crash to desktop. As for the music, it's okay, typical sci-fi action game music. The voice actors did a good job, but the biggest plus of all this are great visual, and sound effects.
[h1]Summary[/h1]
A shooter classic, and a good game that is basically a game version of old American movies. A lot of good fun that doesn't require a lot of brain-usage from us. While it's nothing super special, I still think it's the best Crysis game out there.

Ever since I was a boy, pining for time to play on the diminutive Game-Cube with my friends in 2007, I knew of this game.
"The game of the future" as some said, "Unbelievable graphics!" and "A game so advanced, you need a computer from NASA to run it!"
Now that I'm grown, have my own beefy computer, and the game has a modern remaster to pull it to relevance a decade and a half later - I thought I'd give this remnant from the past a shot and see what I was missing out on.

Mind you, I have no rosy lens or nostalgia goggles when I see this game, and I wasn't expecting to be blown away or witness some legendary epiphany of gaming through this - I was expecting a fun, entertaining game.

It is a shame that I found a great deal of disappointment and mediocrity where I was expecting thrill and fun.

The presentation alone is a specific taste. The mid-2000's was known for this cringe-inducing irreverence and "too cool" pretense that saturated entertainment and made games like Halo a poetic masterpiece in relativity, and this game is no different as a product of that era. Characters talk as though they are in a Saturday morning cartoon, everything feels disjointed and dulled as though its intended market was around the age of 10.
While the premise begins interesting, it doesn't take long for things to devolve.
While the marketing material and all of the best gameplay points to an immersive shooter, the truth is that the creators modeled their work after Call Of Duty 2 and 3 - which achieved near parody of Modern Warfare which came out that very same year. Instead of focusing entirely on the solid core of shooter gameplay, the game constantly introduces setpieces and new mechanics that last for a level (Or sometimes only a part of a level) which throw the entire tone off from being an immersive piece into being a wacky, zany comic book from history's dust-bin.

This remaster has done a lot to bring the game into the modern landscape, but there's only so much that a Remaster can do to turn a 15 year old game into a relevant technological marvel. Once I toned Raytracing down, my computer was running more than fine with only a few dropped frames at intense moments of the game - but in the end, there are a lot more visually impressive experiences around today, or even from many years ago. Textures are low resolution, god-rays look like a flat widget, dust effects are cheap. While the game was ahead of its time with things like Real-Time-Shadows and the sort, such comforts are not nearly as stone-cold impressive as they must have been back when Call Of Duty: Modern Warfare was released. Simply put: Its main selling point has failed to stand the test of time, what was once jaw-dropping and ground breaking has become a modern convenience.

When you get into the game, the dissonance begins to creep in like an insidious illness. Within a few minutes, the most optimal strategy will become clear: Use your cloak to line up a headshot, uncloack and shoot, recloak instantly, move a little and repeat.
The combat aspects were ahead of its time, indeed, as the game feels like an unholy mixture of Call Of Duty games blended with Far Cry. But, as one may remember, Call Of Duty and Far Cry games are all about aggression and speed - but Crysis, on the other hand, revolves around a more methodical approach. The two aspects of gameplay are laid out plain to see: on one hand you have an incredibly fast-paced power fantasy with superhuman powers that allow players to become a walking army... on the other there is an ultra-realistic hardcore simulator that wants to break your bones for broth. These two elements clash. Does the game want you to sit behind cover as you're pinned down by a turret, waiting for an opportunity to run to the next foxhole like Call Of Duty - does it want you frantically fleeing into the woods to lay an ambush like Far Cry - or does it want you to storm in like a super-soldier and trash the place? Answer: None of the above, but all at the same time. It's a mess. The most efficient way to play is the most boring.
Something more at the game's core is the Energy System. Everything you do costs Energy: Running, Jumping, Throwing, Cloaking, Armor. And it takes ~10s to replentish. During this time, you will basically have to wait before you continue playing the game. As a loose calculation, I suspect that ~10s out of every 70 that I played this game, I was simply WAITING for my energy to return so I can get back to playing it. Which means that, in my 7 hours of playing the game, nearly 1 HOUR of it was me WAITING to jump, sprint, interact, cloak, or have armor.
To make matters worse - AI is severely lacking. The basic grunts are generally brick-stupid and make for easy fodder, but more 'advanced' enemies later in the game follow a formulaic move-set that players will learn in a matter of seconds, and then have to endure for another couple of hours. It is not an engaging interaction between man and machine as much as a test of patience.
Grunts were bad enough, but the game forces a couple of extremely contrives and laughably bad "boss fights" your way at a few points, which are so poor - it begs the question "Why even bother?"
The most blatant misplay of all was the lack of collectables, secrets, or character growth. Abilities cannot be expanded upon or increased, weapons will always be disposable, no hidden collectable items, no secret power ups, no "true ending". It's just the same march from A to B every game with a static player and static gameplay. There are no dynamics in play outside of the visual presentation. With a few exceptions of strange puzzles that don't belong in this game at all.

And in spite of levels appearing open-ended, they are all linear in every practical way.

I used a term to describe the game experience to my wife: "The Thin Cloak Of Immersion"
I love IM-Sims, where players get into the mind of the character and project an attitude as though the events of the game are real or serious by nature. Playing this way in Crysis, I had an enjoyable time sleuthing past enemies, knocking out foes, and killing rival soldiers when they saw me to best conceal the truth of my nature... but after a meaningless death for a silly reason or another (Falling, random land mine, pressed the wrong button, etc.) the Immersion was broken like tension on a water's surface. Fickle and fleeting as it was, I had fun trying to extract some semblance of immersion, but the truth is that the game is such a trial of endurance - the first sacrifice to play is Immersion itself.
This was a big lesson that I learned from this game - Time is the enemy of immersion. And a game that demands players use TIME as a currency to play, will never draw players in.
The other lesson that I learned from this game is that POLISH < SUBSTANCE. While a well polished product, Crysis simply lacks substance to elevate it over the other offerings in this day and age.

What holds it back is not so much negativity, but mediocrity.
The only thing worse than an unspeakably bad game is one so tortuously boring that it feels like a chore to play.
It got to the point where I was tabbing out of the game to get some remote work done in my spare time.
You heard that right.
I literally was so bored with the game I chose to do WORK over playing it.

~

TL;DR
5/10
Crysis is an Average game. (Painfully so)
it feels like a very ambitious tech demo, but what holds it back the most is that on one side it has a comic book power fantasy, and on the other it has an immersive, serious simulator presentation - and the two clash horrendously throughout the playthrough. In spite of its ambitions to spark a flame that will elevate it into stardom, this game has been left in the cold - buried deep down and forgotten under a mountainous island of superior alternatives.
