THIS is one of the examples as why "good graphics =/= good game" and one of the examples of PERFECT mediocrity by Triple As; just a paint-over of "Looks nice" with a peppering of "Cool" stuffs over an outdated shooter that, once just SLIGHTLY played, immediately breaks immersion and gives away the clunkiness and jankiness IN A BAD WAY

Positives
+ Nice graphics (But, technically speaking, if you like pretty graphics and don't mind gameplay, just go watch a benchmark screensaver, since their graphics are SOOOO GOOOOD and you don't mind crappy gameplay, right?)
+ Collapsible/Destructible environment

Negatives
- Unintuitive AI; a Remaster and they make ZERO changes to the AI; no flanking, no ganking, they group up like 7 y.o. kids playing football (even in-game convos suggest "these guys are trouble") but hey sure, the "elite badass" troops bunch around waiting for a grenade to be popped on their feet, yet they themselves almost never use grenades DESPITE being bottle-necked and killed off 1 by 1 for the last 2-3 minutes and doesn't encircle to gank despite being able to talk.. OH WOW MUCH ELITE, SUCH BADASS, VERY SOLDIER, KEKG
*Go play Stalker Anomaly for an example of Intuitive AI (which, btw, is a 2004 game by a small company modded and updated even until 2021)

- ZERO Multi-approach; "Oh, a different branching path? SIKE it's just a 10 metre-difference vantage point that gives you a slight advantage over YET ANOTHER of the HUNDREDS of 3-5 people brain-dead mobs
*Go play the Dishonored series for a great example of multi-approach that ACTUALLY makes a difference in story progression, upgrade system, and ending

- Weapon variability; with a remaster, at least you'd consider weapon degradation (just for hardest difficulty is fine, just AT LEAST make an effort to make things different), rewarding exploration with different mods for your weapons, or dropships for your suit upgrades (since, you know, your MOST ELITE JSOC soldiers are in trouble in a remote island). The weapon mods are just 3-5 things that you'll only change 1 every 30 min or so (I only swapped between reflex sight and assault scope for my single-shot silencer AK for 1/3 of the game, simply because switching other mods in other weapons does not bring any difference nor variability to the way i approach objectives anyways)

- Gameplay Loop (or, in simpler terms, Addictiveness); Crysis is basically "Fight this 3-7 people brain-dead mobs with this slightly cool suit with ONLY 4 functions" repeated ad nauseum. No effort whatsoever in the remaster to add new gameplay elements whatsoever, improve existing AI or interaction, nope, nothing... even the options to interact with the suit functions feels counter-intuitive (why is there no options to quickly toggle between "normal" shield mode with "heavy shield" mode on PC? the elite of the elite suits for TACTICAL COMBAT and they can't make this distinction???)
*The perfect example of excellent gameplay loop is Dredge; ironically i just played it before this, a LITERAL FISHING GAME less than 1 GB is so well-designed it's actually MORE FUN than a shooter with "one of the best graphics" in terms of gameplay loop

- Scripted scenes; in one of the missions, I'm cloaked, sneaking around the forest, suddenly the detection bar jumps up to max, a group of soldiers insta-appears right in front of me, then stand there doing nothing and the previously max-out detection bar jumps to 3/4 and start lowering... This is just one of the examples of badly designed scripted scenes, and is a stellar example of lazy game design; mind you, I'm not trying to break the game nor glitch it, I'm simply using the stealth-mechanics AS INTENDED lore- and gameplay-wise
*Plenty of games have cleverly designed scripted scenes that feels "natural"; Sekiro, Deus Ex, Fallout NV, that does not break immersion in such a jarring way


TLDR; One-dimensional shooter with the same "here's 3-7 brain-dead AI enemies that can't even comprehend where you are even when their friend was shot ONE METER IN FRONT of them" gameplay loop repeated ad nauseum, a seemingly cool tactical suit that's actually counter-intuitive (in PC at least) designed to impress 7-14 year-olds by visuals

(ironically, the only reason i played is because i remembered back then the only good thing regarding this game is its graphics, and i wanted to reconfirm, in case I'm wrong LOL)

Crysis — це весела, гарна гра, яка, зрештою, не відповідає початковим обіцянкам своїх перших рівнів. У неї все одно варто грати, навіть якщо це лише для того, щоб відчути цікаві здібності нанокостюма та дивуватися тому, що було і є дуже гарною грою.

Перші кілька рівнів — це великі відкриті середовища, які дають вам свободу підходу до їхніх цілей. Але це вірно лише в самому буквальному сенсі; ви можете підійти до цілей з будь-якого напрямку, тому що ви не обмежені прямолінійним шляхом. Але на цьому свобода закінчується; немає жодних варіантів щодо того, як ви фактично виконуєте поставлені перед вами завдання, або будь-яких варіантів ігрового процесу в стилі «імерсивного симулятора».

Після цих перших рівнів гра стає більш схожою на лінійний шутер. Це все ще цікаво, але це, мабуть, не те, за чим ви прийшли чи очікували.

У найскладнішому режимі гра здебільшого на диво легка, з дуже щедрим відновленням здоров’я та щита та великою кількістю доступних боєприпасів. Здатність нанокостюма зробити вас надсильним, невидимим або дуже швидким означає, що ви можете легко маневрувати ворогами, а будь-яке випробування насправді виникає лише завдяки тому, що ви першим стріляєте у будь-якого ворога, якого зустрінете.

Найбільше розчарування від Crysis полягає в тому, що з більшості зброї нудно стріляти. Існує чудова система, за допомогою якої ви можете змінювати навісні пристрої зброї на ходу, але ви ніколи не отримаєте справді захоплюючу зброю, за винятком, можливо, ракетної установки (коли ракетна установка взагалі не весела?)

Цей оновлений здебільшого добре, хоча є деякі досить серйозні проблеми з балансуванням звуку та моменти, коли звукові ефекти чи музика не чутні, коли вони повинні бути. Транспортні засоби, які знаходяться за сотні метрів, звучать так, ніби вони прямо на вас, дивні речі в цьому роді. Ця версія гри також використовує систему контрольних точок без ручного збереження, що є справді поганою заміною.

Це рекомендація з кількома застереженнями, але здебільшого я добре провів час. Дещо про костюм, який сповіщає про "Плащ. Заручено". викликає у мене викид дофаміну, так що лише це було варте ціни!

Is this "remaster" good? No... Crysis Remaster is quite possibly the most unnecessary and maybe even worst "remaster" of all time. For every improvement this "remaster" provides there is also a downgrade of equal or greater impact. I would recommend you instead purchase the "Crysis Maximum Edition" which includes the original PC version of the game as well as the "Crysis Warhead" standalone expansion, which has never gotten the "remastered" treatment yet.

Why is Crysis Remastered such a mixed bag? Crysis Remastered is based on the console ports of the game rather than the original PC version and uses a newer version of Cryengine. I'm not going to cover all the pros and cons of the graphics as there are numerous resources that already cover that such as this video I recommend you watch: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lxBTgRcHYFA.

Although I recommend the original Crysis over Crysis Remastered, here are some important points that may make Crysis Remastered a better option for you:
- Crysis Remastered has Steam achievements while Crysis does not.
- Crysis Remastered runs on the Steam Deck while Crysis does not.
- Crysis Remastered allows options for simplified and classic suit ability controls while Crysis only allows classic suit ability controls.

NOTE: Keep in mind that numerous things were patched into Crysis Remastered after it's original release, so although it is still not a good "remaster" it has been made better than the original reviews. For example, the "Ascension" level was not included, the classic suit abilities were not an option, and their were major performance issues, but each of those has been added or improved via patches.

All that being said, I will still be giving this a recommendation, because at the end of the day it is still "Crysis" and it is one of my favorite first person shooter games and franchises.

Wow! Saber Interactive managed to take everything that was annoying about the original Crysis and turn it up to eleven. For the most part it's still a pretty fun game but the goddamn alien cave was a pain in the original, but forgivable as it was a new thing then. But, as they chose to cut certain parts from Remastered because "players really didn't like it" (The Acension level) they left in the singular worst and most frustrating part of the damn game, the "core" alien cave. Worse still THEY MADE IT EVEN MORE INFURIATING. They did make some changes... IN THE WRONG DIRECTION adding to the frustration/BOREDOM-THAT-NEVER-ENDS when they could have left it in for story purposes but streamlined it for a less flow and momentum breaking effect instead of leaving the abominable aspect.

I didn't rage quit this game, I bored quit it after wasting over an hour of my life wandering around the cave aimlessly trying to find a way out. SHITTY SHITTY UNFORGIVABLE game design! Now I'm going to "bored uninstall" it. Then I'm going to "bored pan review" it straight to hell because it's no less that it deserves.

Stay away from this game unless you have a perverse masochistic desire to waste time in the senseless alien cave accomplishing nothing, and you MUST endure this torture if want to progress in the game.

There's just no excuse for this kind of design in a fast paced action game. At least check videos on ScreYouTube and watch the sequence to get an idea if you can endure the suffering first.

Also, as a parting shot, the elimination of a proper save system in favor of a "checkpoint system" is a major faux pas! It's an indicator of "console-itis disease". I'd like to save my game progress at need because I don't know when mom might demand I take out the trash or my wife may demand I go to my mother-in-law's place for diner.  Instead I'm stuck with saving when the game gives me permission (unlike the original). Sometimes I'm sleepy NOW! Not when the game thinks I should be. Shouldn't I be allowed to save and quit the game at need. Besides, what happens when I want to go back prior the the last checkpoint? Restart level? Great, another 45 minutes of my life gone when I could have simply reloaded a 10 minute save.

Also, one of the things I enjoy in a game is saving a certain point and experimenting with different tactics, methods weapons and outcomes, which is especially true of the Crysis series. Often I'll reload and try a different tactic even If my last tactic was successful. The checkpoint system robs us of that opportunity to experiment and cheapens the experience and the value of the game. Which is a shame considering that the save game implementation has been baked right into the game's code (even the Remastered version). It has even been a request to be re-implemented in a patch and has been continuously ignored. But why should they bother to honor requests once they have your dollar.

I have played Crysis on release day and cleared it dozens of times and a dozen ways.  The spawning system an open maps (very large open maps, but not true open world) make it so every single playthrough is different past the first few kills in the first village area you approach, but that is the tutorial.

It is the BEST first person shooter ever created in my opinion for 2 reasons.  It was a decade ahead of its time and it needed the best pc at the time, but that is not why.  Its innovation, which the series itself dropped in the sequels has still not been rivaled in any game I have seen.  In the field as bullets are flying modification of any weapon you pick up is one thing but a physics sandbox on top of it makes it special, Chop down trees, blow em up, use your super suit to punch down most walls except reinforced concrete and so on.

Open world, every fight based on the spawn system is different in every playthrough and the modification system was great and I was hoping that they would take this awesome baseline and innovate but they didn't.  They regressed making a Crysis 2 and 3 a corridor shooter.

I hope Warhawk gets remade as well, unless somehow I missed that it was part of the remaster as it is the same game from a 2nd character's point of view and different missions.

They had basic vehicle combat and you could tell they planned on flight combat in future release, especially with the surprise enemy at the end 1/3rd of the game, but nope.  Bow and Arrow, different character and boring storyline about the suit rather than the secret enemy hit the sequels.

I will be playing the sequels for my 2nd time since i got them in this package but probably that 2nd time only.  However every year or so I will pop in Crysis and play through it with a different style that time.  As with release there are a few times you crash but luckily it is right at a checkpoint.  They never fixed the save system.

Besides that one problem, you should try it.  Especially now that it is cheaper and remade with modern graphics.

Crysis should have been the template for all FPS shooters going forward.  Realistic, Sci-Fi, modern, etc...  all could have been improved with the systems in Crysis but for some reason or another they made the sequels for a more casual audience that did not want to approach a KPA group will crab crawling prone to sneak in, map the enemy's location (which differs based on several factors beside random, like if you went loud in a close by place or enemy, they are already on the mounted guns and patrolling with intent or took out everything quietly or completely stealthed, with no kills except the tranquilizer (tactical attachment) dart.

If you like Military Shooters and Sci-Fi and prefer gameplay over graphics then you will dig this.  It was praised for its graphics at the time but its systems were what makes it a non-stop fun lifetime game.

Decent game, horrible remaster.

This is a game that I’ve played since 2007, I still have my physical copy of it on my shelf and I’ve played it many times with many hardware configurations, so without a shadow of a doubt, I kinda have a feeling when a scene is rendered correctly or not.

I played this remaster from start to finish with Ray Tracing [b]ON[/b] and it sure does look absolutely beautiful, one of the best looking games of 2007 is still one of the best looking games in 2023, no question about it. But it only looks great in very specific circumstances, for example, in bright daylight the RT technology shines (no pun intended), but in the second half of the game which involves a lot of dark areas and a lot of snow, you’d be hard pressed to tell if RT is still being used if it wasn’t for the performance hit.

The last level was particularly painful for how darn DARK it gets, there’s a certain lab scene that makes it unreasonably dark when there’s like 5 people in the same room, it sure as heck should be a lot brighter with that many people in it. 

Not only the dark scenes get comically dark, but I’ve also found plenty of gameplay bugs, especially in the second half, like rocks that sway back and forth like leaves, soldiers getting stuck in important doorways, dialogues that trigger a second time in a row after going back to where the trigger was, music cutting in and out… I understand this is an old game with very different tech than what is considered standard nowadays, but it sure as heck didn’t feel like it was falling apart like a house made out of sticks and glue with a shiny polish.

And that’s without mentioning how bad they screwed with the controls, Saber Interactive, in their infinite wisdom, wanted the controls to feel closer to it’s sequels, but it only feels like a forced, dumbed down version of the original without the tight feel of the sequels, fortunately you can go back to the original controls, but ALSO they took away the quick save feature in place of a crappy checkpoint system without letting you pick from earlier saves if you somehow get screwed by said system.

I’m in a sort of predicament with this review, I do not recommend this remaster because of how buggy it felt throughout my playthrough, but I also hesitate to recommend the original release instead because of how hard it is to make it run at reasonable framerates on modern computers. 

Don't buy the original on Steam, instead I’d recommend the GOG release of the original Crysis along with Warhead, you can get both for dirt cheap and they both already have most fixes applied, namely without DRM --which was a big issue with both games back in the day.

Game is still worth playing, but stay away from this remaster.

Crysis Remastered - это переиздание популярной игры Crysis, которая была выпущена в 2007 году. Игра разработана Saber Interactive и Crytek, а издателем является Crytek.

Достоинства Crysis Remastered:

1. Графика: одним из главных достоинств игры является улучшенная графика. Улучшенные текстуры, тени и освещение в игре делают ее более красивой и реалистичной. Это создает атмосферную игровую обстановку, которая помогает игроку более глубоко погрузиться в игровой мир.

2. Игровой процесс: игровой процесс в Crysis Remastered сохраняет ту же механику, что и в оригинальной игре. Игрокам предоставляются различные варианты прохождения уровней благодаря свободной структуре уровней и разнообразию оружия. Игровой процесс сохраняется более чем за десять лет после первого релиза.

3. Искусственный интеллект: в Crysis Remastered значительно улучшен искусственный интеллект противников. Это делает их более умными и агрессивными, что позволяет игроку находить новые подходы к решению задач. Более разнообразные тактики и более сложный игровой процесс помогут сохранить интерес игроков.

4. Улучшенная оптимизация: улучшенная оптимизация позволяет игре работать лучше на более слабых компьютерах, чем оригинал. Она также обеспечивает стабильный кадровый поток, что не разрывает игровой процесс и позволяет наслаждаться игрой.

Недостатки Crysis Remastered:

1. Мало изменений: Crysis Remastered не добавляет много нового к игре, кроме улучшенной графики. Игра сохраняет ту же самую сюжетную линию, механику и особенности, что может быть разочаровывающим для тех, кто ожидал больше изменений.

2. Ошибки и баги: Crysis Remastered содержит некоторые ошибки и баги, которые могут встречаться во время игры. Некоторые пользователи сообщают о проблемах с синхронизацией звука и видео, некоторые утверждают, что игра иногда имеет проблемы с переключением режимов визуальных эффектов. Все это может влиять на качество игрового процесса и вызывать раздражение у игроков.

3. Отсутствие многопользовательского режима: Crysis Remastered не содержит многопользовательский режим, что может разочаровать некоторых игроков, которые ожидали возможность сыграть с друзьями в онлайн-режиме. Однако, оригинальная игра была изначально спроектирована для однопользовательского прохождения, так что это не является большим недостатком для игры.

4. Высокие требования к системе: хотя Crysis Remastered имеет улучшенную оптимизацию, игра все же имеет высокие требования к системе. Для достижения наилучшего игрового опыта игрокам придется иметь достаточно мощный компьютер, что может быть проблемой для тех, кто хочет играть на старых или бюджетных компьютерах.

В целом, Crysis Remastered является хорошим переизданием оригинальной игры. Улучшенная графика, игровой процесс и искусственный интеллект противников помогают улучшить игровой опыт, но некоторые игроки могут быть разочарованы отсутствием нового контента и проблемами с ошибками и багами. Однако, если вы любите оригинальную игру Crysis, то Crysis Remastered является хорошим выбором для повторного прохождения этой классической игры.

As someone who never got to play the original, this was an interesting play. I can see why the physics and graphics combined with the semi-open world garnered so much hype around it in 2007. Playing it in 2023 however feels pretty mediocre. The gameplay is stiff and clunky, the stealth system is pretty awfull (enemies spot you through objects at any range as long as they have line of sight) and the story and lore is barebones.

I did enjoy most of the first half of the game once I got used to the clunkyness and learned to weave in and out of combat rather than go full stealth, but the second half diminished that enjoyment. 

It is one of those game where I wish Steam had a "netutral" option, but I choose to recommend it due to it's legacy, and the fact that it is, except for some slight visual polish, a 16 year old game which has held up pretty well.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Note: I did my very first and only (as of this review) playthrough (~6-7 hours) on Delta difficulty, the hardest one to choose from.

You're a soldier, part of a squad enhanced with nanosuits, set out to find what the Koreans are up to on this rather bleak island.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
This game is a lot of fun. It's a staple of its time: the era of single-player action-story games. It's linear in terms of objectives—as was the standard in its era—but it's for good reason. It features "secondary objectives," but really they feel more like additional objectives. They're along the way to the main objective and are really hard to miss.

There's this one section that stands out to me, it's where you get to pilot and fight with a tank. The vista is amazing and grand. It captures the pure contrast between a paradise-like island and opposing forces fighting against each other.

Stealth is also done in an engaging manner. Not only do you have to manage your suit energy and de-cloak a opportune times, but also doing any kind of offensive action (like shooting) while cloaked drains all your suit energy. This means to pull off stealth kills, you have to de-cloak -> shoot -> cloak in rapid succession.

The hardest difficulty, delta, forces disabled crosshair, does something with binoculars (I do not know what exactly as I have not tested/looking into it), and makes enemies speak Korean instead of English. Why these options are limited to difficulty is an odd choice. I noticed that no crosshairs makes gameplay a lot more immersive. Would be interesting to see more games of the modern era come out with options to limit visibility of HUD elements (like Dark Souls/Elden Ring hiding the UI when out of combat) to improve the immersion.

[h1]DIFFICULTY[/h1]
The difficulty scaling is a nice balance, at the highest difficulty it's hard enough that you cannot go-in guns blazing with no effort, but also not frustratingly unbalanced. It might be a little on the easier side, but I'd say it's practically balanced by having both you and the enemy be glass cannons, you both can deal a lot of damage, but also receive that same amount of damage. You can also pick up enemies (which, note, kills them instantly once you throw them), which is a load of fun and has a nice risk/reward to it when out of stealth engagements. There is a specific enemy in the later game that can be a little more tough, and being able to pick them up screams "nanosuit soldier" and it's really cool.

AI can be a little dumb and unfair at times (note: AI have some very good eyes, i.e. being in their line of sight is enough to get instantly spotted, despite there being a reasonable amount of foliage in front of you), but they are rather unique. AI will attempt to shoot in the general location you were upon cloaking, which is a nice feature. Tanks can also instantly spot you if you get too close even while cloaked, which doesn't make much sense, but it doesn't matter much because it's practically a non-issue with how the game plays out

[h1]REMARKS[/h1]
Something really nice about this game is dynamic crouch/sprint context. You can tap crouch/sprint to make it act like tap crouch/sprint; you can also hold crouch/sprint to make it act like hold crouch/sprint, where you will stop crouching/sprinting after releasing the key. This is a very nice feature that would be really cool to see in modern games.

Although my system is rather weak (1650 mobile) and the game ran a "smooth" 20-30 FPS on all low settings like a Captain Underpants fight sequence, it still looked amazing. This game is [i]very[/i] graphically intensive, making my GPU work absolute overtime and a half at a constant 100% usage. It does not, however, make much use of the CPU, as only about 20-40% was reported to be used by the entire system throughout while playing.

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
Crysis is essentially an interactive action movie. You can tell the passion poured into the game, it's definitely worth the price. If you're looking for a fun experience, you'll get one.

This game is quite good.  I wasn't sure what to expect after I read some of the previous comments.  I find that what was complained about isn't really there.  The graphics are quite good and will be better with the best video cards, with a very smooth frame rate on a 3070 class video card at 2K with high settings.  This is way better than when the game first came out.  The game play is remarkably good for such an old game and even though I finished the game years ago, I still am enjoying it more than the first time around.  I would say the AI is actually quite good and the gun play after getting used to the more smooth recoil is a blast.

The Pros:
*  Smooth graphics, very high quality with a reasonable card.  This will only get better upwards of 4k with high settings, if not max.
*  The game plays better overall now that there is no "lag" anywhere.
*  The AI is actually pretty decent.
*  The sound is quite good, including the hit indicators on enemies.

The Cons:
*  Still requires a very hot graphics card to turn EVERYTHING on.  DLSS is very good on this game build.

If you haven't played the game, its pretty good even by modern standards.  If you have played it, its still better than the first time around.

Pros:
* Has a field of view slider but it can only go up to a max of 80

Cons:
* The multiplayer gamemode was not included in Crysis Remastered when it was available in the original game
* I have a 5950x and a RTX 4090 yet my game sometimes will drop below 60 FPS at 4k with all settings, included ray tracing, maxed out
* The AI is dumb to where it can bug out

Other thoughts:
* The game does start off pretty slow
* A recent patch restored back the campaign level called "Ascension" along with a few control options
* Not much replayability due to the lack of multiplayer and mods compared to the original game
* I enjoyed the lore since I find an alien invasion to be fascinating
* I recommend in trying it out when it's on sale; otherwise don't bother. It feels like a game that you pick up to complete the campaign once and that's it.
* I have not stumble into any game breaking bugs but I will leave this link here https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Crysis_Remastered
* Game's version as of this review is 1.0.0.1

A classic reborn with some tweaks

People often think of Crysis as a shallow tech demo game versus an actual fully formed open world romp. You are on an island, you get objectives, now go explore and find ways to complete those objectives. Its a semi-linear branching path where you can do all sorts of mayhem in the destructible game world. Its a simple plot, nothing too deep here, but enjoyable all the same.

Its a short romp, only about 6-7 hours, probably about 15 if you wanna replay on the Delta difficulty and go for all the achievements. But it doesnt really overstay its welcome. 

The remaster of the game has some simplified control options (and the ability to go back to classic) but it can feel a bit clunky at times, especially picking up ammo and weapons can feel very..well.. frustrating at times, not helped by them sometimes clipping through terrain. 

The big highlight on the remaster is the RT reflections, which are really cool and add a lot to the game, in fact the RT and SVOGI implementation makes the game look absolutely stunning if you have the hardware to run it, but it is an older game and there are limits to it compared to more modern titles

Would I recommend it? Yes I think I would to anyone just getting into PC gaming, Its a classic and a game that crushed PC hardware 15 years ago and with RT, manages to strain it today. Just remember its a 15 year old game and it has its quirks.

Recommended, but only as part of the Crysis Remastered Trilogy bundle. Note that it doesn't feature multiplayer, and there are no cloud saves at time of writing.

The Remaster:
- This is an interesting remaster since it's not built on the original engine of the PC version of Crysis, resulting in some gameplay differences, notably AI not behaving quite the same. It's not a big deal if you've never played the game before since the general gameplay features are still there, but if you've played the original on PC the experience is a bit different. There is also a revised set of Nanosuit controls, which I think is designed to function more like Crysis 2 and 3, but I never actually tested them and instead used the classic Nanosuit controls that behave like the original Crysis.
- Performance wise things aren't too bad if you change a few settings to avoid CPU problems: if you put objects to high, vegetation and shadows to medium / high, you get a level of detail and draw distance that's similar or better than the original game for increased performance, and most other settings (apart from ray tracing) can be turned up to maximum without much impact. Another advantage of the remaster is that it works out of the box on Windows 10, whereas the original game requires user fixes to launch at all.
- In terms of graphics, it's a bit of a mixed bag. The updated assets generally look quite nice, but compared to the original the colour tone is a bit over-saturated during the day, yet the dawn and dusk sequences have less atmosphere. There are ray traced reflections too which are nice to have if you've got the hardware, though the number of reflective surfaces is a bit limited in many areas.
- Unfortunately there are a few annoying problems with the remaster. I had to use console commands to set additional min and max sensitivity values, as the menu slider didn't give me a low enough value, but then the tank had a ridiculously low sensitivity so I had to change them during gameplay too. There are also some audio problems, such as shooting an enemy from long distance and his shouts from being hit are like he's right in front of your face, and there are other similar imbalances which don't help with positional audio and dialogue during gameplay either.

Conclusion:
- Overall it's not a terrible remaster, but I feel like the lack of polish and some of the visual changes hamper it a bit, and given how iconic the original was for PC gaming at the time, I recommend playing the original first if you can just for the classic experience. That said, the remaster is worth a play if you get it as part of the Crysis Remastered Trilogy bundle, and if you've never played the original the remaster will still give you the general gameplay feel so you're not missing out, without any fixes required to get it running either.

The Game:
- The first half of the game features sandbox levels where you fight the Korean army using your Nanosuit features for temporary increases in speed, strength, or a cloak for near invisibility. You can interact with just about anything; picking up objects and throwing them, shooting down small trees, destroying buildings, and driving around in vehicles. You can acquire shotguns, assault rifles, a sniper rifle and more, picking up attachments along the way such as lasers, scopes and grenade launchers. This gives a good variety of options for traversing the tropical island and completing objectives - you can go in guns blazing or sneak around with the cloak etc.
- The second half of the game is where most people's complaints come from. It becomes increasingly linear, and you start fighting aliens instead with a reduced amount of combat options. I personally don't mind it that much, but the first half of the game is definitely where things shines and why (in combination with the visuals) it was so iconic back in the day.

Crysis Remastered does pretty much everything wrong. Yes, they added back the deleted level eventually, and they did fix the worst of the performance issues, but this is still a technical mess with settings that break.

But the biggest problems are how this remaster completely ruins everything Crysis stood for. Go look at the official trailers and footage of Crysis, and you'll see how modding was one of its main features. This remaster is unmoddable, you can't even alter nanosuit parameters as the console commands don't do anything. This, combined with the slightly worse balance of the nanosuit, makes strength mode practically useless. Using strength mode to throw objects at enemies, or punch objects into enemies, was one of the most fun ways to kill people, and it's no longer valid here.

The movement is also dumbed down, inherited from Crysis 3 so you are pretty much immobile in the air now. Crysis and Crysis Warhead had many advanced nanosuit movements, especially in the air, which added a new dimension to its gameplay and increased the skill curve. Though this was mostly relevant to multiplayer rather than single player, which brings me to my next point.

The biggest mistake this remaster makes is not remastering the multiplayer, which was another major feature of Crysis (as much as single player was). Crysis and Crysis Wars were some of the best PvP shooters of all time, featuring one of the best ever and most strategic combined arms game modes called Power Struggle, having a bigger skill curve than most (more than Quake and UT, arguably more than CS), having tons of content, and again being super moddable. 

Even though the original Crysis is broken on Windows 10 and 11, it's the better version to play. I recommend playing it with Tactical Expansion mod. Crysis Wars multiplayer is also still technically functional, you can join the Crysis Wars discord to organize matches.

Get it on a discount if you haven't played it.

Game is great, Crysis has always had some of the most interactive game play out of anything I've ever played. Cloaking System is fun, Max Armor makes Survivability on many missions much easier.

The game has some minor issues regarding graphics, only problem I ran into was the Laser pointer glitching and making a massive red glare on my screen pointing in different directions.

I never had the pleasure of playing the original, but I'd have to say, the original will probably always hold up better than the remaster, nostalgia will always make it seem better than it actually was. 

One thing some people fail to realize is that most companies when they remaster games only "improve" upon the graphics, they don't offer any extra content for players to experience, only enhancing it by making it more immersive with a more realistic feel, they tried to keep the game in a retro style by adding RayTracking and "Can it Run Crysis" but keeping the old models with slightly better graphics, giving it a Halo Master Chief Collection feel (Halo CE updated graphics mode). 

Overall I'd have to say that if you want to experience this game, you should play the original, unfortunately they removed the ability to purchase the original from the steam store quite some time ago. 

Missions were fun and weren't too difficult playing on Normal Mode, I was able to beat it within 12 hours (3 of the 15.7 hours played was me falling asleep on the couch lol). Once you reach the core of the Mountain tho things start to fall apart, games becomes much more over tuned and the feel starts to diminish, game was much more fun when fighting the Koreans and not the Aliens. Beating the game doesn't feel very rewarding as the final mission is buggy and you tend to get frozen very often when fighting the final boss, the mechanics are over tuned as if its a newly released World of Warcraft raid that no one is able to get past 90% health. My Tip to beating the final boss with little to no frustration is by hiding next to the Forklift on the right side of the Carrier ship and cloaking right before the Mother Ship tries to 1 shot you, it prevents the cruisers from attacking you and allows you to pop out of cloak for a split second to nuke the wings and then the core, you have to sit IDLE for a good 3 mins before the fight will end, otherwise it'll freeze you over and over again killing you because you can't play. (Getting Frozen also prevents you from using Max Armor, meaning you just get chain frozen and die due to the beam and cruisers)

Final Words would have to be: If you want to play it, do it, but i recommend buying it with the Trilogy so you can get access to the other 2 games, its not worth buying it on its own, especially with the sales (I purchases it during the 2022 Winter Sale)

Good Luck, Have fun, and f*** the final mission.

Some of the sloppiest 'remaster' design choices I've ever experienced; but still one of the best games ever made.

Pros:
- Plays almost identically to the original.  A successful port of the maps and combat.
- New Ray-Tracing looks stunning and adds much more realism and depth to the environment.  
- I didn't have a crash throughout my entire playthrough.  The original never ran stably for me; on 5 different systems....

Cons:
- Many cutscenes have been worsened by goofy lighting, animation glitches, and the occasional audio glitch (late music, missing lipsyncing for 1 line of dialogue etc)
- QuickSaving requires a MOD.  I realize the other Crysis games were Auto-Save only, but the more linear gameplay allows for that.  Experimenting with the AI, physics, and combat mechanics were part of what made the original Crysis so replayable and it's an essential part of the experience!
- The game has been 'reshaded' with too much saturation for my taste.  The game feels much more 'cheerful' than the original.  The aliens are less scary as a result, too.

Recommend only on deep sale or if you've never experienced the original.

This game was the pinnacle of graphics back in the day. I remember buying a new graphic card twice plus a fresh set of RAM to max out all the details and it looked incredible - still with 30frames max but as long it looked great who cared :) 
The remaster had a rough start at release, right now in its current state it plays nice, but there are still some bugs around. Some of them you may know from the original game, most of them are new, at least for myself. Especially at the end of the game they where quite some of them around, but nothing game breaking. Sometimes the frames dropped for a few seconds for whatever reason, sometimes there's no muzzle flash, invisible walls or rubber banding. Also I had a weird facial animation bug one time. When having the "reduced movement" bug just change weapons and you're good. 

In its core its still Crysis of course, it will always be one of my fav games, but besides the updated graphics (raytracing looks great) I'd still prefer the original, maybe with some mods. Textures where updated and looked nice in 4K, but they forgot soem spot here and there.

Achievment wise its very easy, got all of them in one run under 10 hours. Delta difficulty is pretty easy, thanks to your suit. I recommend to start "Marathon man" early on so you dont have to power-sprint around at the end of the game to pop the achievment. Also look out for the yellow markers for side objectives, but they are very easy to spot, plus the game tells you every time.

Final verdict: If you loved the first one its cool to come back after all these years, if you got the hardware. In 4K it still takes a lot of ressources. There are bugs, but nothing game breaking. Plus, should you be a  completionist like me, its a very easy 100% game when it comes to achievments.

I never played the original version of Crysis so I can't rightly tell you the differences between that and the Remastered version, though I imagine i'll get more of an idea when I play Warhead next (Since that wasn't remastered, as far as I know). What I CAN tell you for those in a similar position, is that Crysis is a short, straight forward FPS title that doesn't do anything particularly new...at the time? possibly groundbreaking...but today it serves as a standard affair.

The shooting feels competent and the small selection of weapons aren't anything too exciting, mostly rifles but they get the job done. I did like the ability to change weapon mods on the fly, though it wasn't a game changer and they were extremely limited, no mods were unique to any particular weapon and they included a silencer, 3 types of scope, some underbarrel attachments i never bothered to use, laserpointer, flash light...basically nothing that actually modified the performance of the weapons themselves, just added an extra feature to them. You'd think the silencer would, in typical FPS fashion, cause the guns to lose firepower, or the laserpointer to increase accuracy. They don't.

The nano-suit definitely seems like an idea in its infancy at this point in the series as there's nothing about it that makes me go WOWOWOWOWOW!? I can only imagine they make it better in the later titles of which i'll find out sooner or later as I intend to play those too. Its fairly simple in function, you can go invisible, harden the suits armour, run fast and jump high, but you can't do any of those at the same time as one another. All those functions consume energy at a high rate and the recharge is slow as shit, so you have to use it wisely. I was wondering early on if id get to upgrade my suit somehow to reduce consumption but after a while I gave up on that idea when i realised it wasn't gonna happen. The game essentially was a case of playing the first half using stealth and the second half using armour when you realise that using stealth is kinda...pointless. I seemed to get spotted regardless and even if I was crouched or prone, some random soldier would see me even when he was facing the other direction. I ended up quickly transitioning in and out of stealth to do quick headshots as shooting while in stealth causes the suit to automatically bust you out of stealth and drain all the energy,. So I eventually just relied on armour instead.

There are several maps you transition between over the course of the games campaign, starting out fairly open world-ish and eventually boil down to very linear paths as the story comes to a head and all taking place on this one island. Honestly, fairly bland map design, nothing really stood out, it was just a lot of shanty shacks and fields of which most you wouldn't ever see due to the immense amount of hand holding between each objective and no actual incentive to explore.

By no means a terrible game and I can see how it can carve a path for its future sequels, just nothing memorable either!

Overall I think this is worth it from a stand point You've never played Crysis before and are new to the series, then yeah get this remaster to not fuck around with the settings to make the original work and welcome to Lingshan. 

BUT if You're a returning fan or You have the original copy of this game I suggest You play the original rather than the remaster, You'll save yourself some money, though You'll have to make the game work properly (probably).

Also, this remaster doesn't come with neither the "Crysis Warhead" I guess You could call that a DLC but it was a whole standalone game where You play as Psycho and get to know what the fuck He was doing, nor the multiplayer function that is in the original (it's dead since gamespy died but I vaguely remember playing mp through Tunngle and the multiplayer is great considering it's basically Battlefield but in Crysis).

[h1]WILL IT RUN CRYSIS? WILL IT!??!!?[/h1]

That famous catchphrase known in PC gaming! For this Remastered Edition though, your PC will undoubtedly run Crysis since it is a pretty average XBOX 360 PORT, sadly. There are some good parts from this PORT and naturally, bad parts too.

So for this CRYSIS REMASTERED Edition, I'll be comparing the original Crysis played back then in 2007 at release and lately, versus the Remastered version that released back in 2021, played at the time of this review.

So, at release back in 2007, I would say I was disappointed with Crysis Original Edition. Very unoptimized and released too soon for its time. About the same as Crytek's first game, Far Cry, that was pretty demanding back in 2004. Crysis OG struggled to run at medium settings. So technically speaking, the game had a harsh launch but wow oh wow, the game was the BEST LOOKING THING EVER... even when playing in a "slideshow mode". Aside from the specs, the gameplay was pretty great which was what made Crysis known with the freedom of approach to the missions. The controls in the original version are very akin to PC gaming. You have the peaking functions where the Remastered Edition removed them (apparently, they got brought back with a patch but I never bothered to use them in the RE). The crosshair in the original is again, very PC-like where the Remastered is the same reticule as the XBOX360. For the powers, you have a wheel and choose on the fly the power you want. On the Remastered, the controls are very like Crysis 2 and Crysis 3, where the controls are more fluid than using that powers wheel. Talking about your nanosuit powers, you do run longer with the speed power in the Remastered edition.

Visually, it shows a lot about the low textures and graphical fidelity on the Remastered edition. The graphics are very downgraded compared to the original Crysis. You can compare them yourself by either playing the game on EA Desktop or GOG... or by watching this YouTube video that compares it all: [url=https://youtu.be/QeWr2-l_CrA] Crysis Remastered Trilogy vs Original [/url]


[h1]POSITIVES:[/h1]
[b]+Nanosuit makes you feel truly powerful
+Even downgraded, the visuals do have its time to shine... except the characters faces
+Cat & mouse play with enemies
+Suit Powers (having different powers for different kind of approaches. The suit powers sounds are more focused in this Remastered which I liked very much! The armour power is more resistant and the speed power can be used longer compared to OG).
+Streamlined controls (using the nanosuit powers is more fluid than the OG version).
+Perfect UltraWide monitor support.
+Razer Synapse integration (makes some good lighting effects! Crysis OG doesn't have Razer integration)
++EA DESKTOP/ORIGIN NOT NEEDED TO PLAY THIS GAME![/b]


[h1]NEGATIVES:[/h1]
[b]-Epic FAIL Game Store exclusivity for launch, just like the previous all Crysis Remastered versions.
-Poor port from the XBOX 360. 
-Graphical downgrade. It is quite noticeable from the characters especially but the gameworld has many poor visuals too, sadly.
-Poor enemy A.I. getting stuck in trees and the like.
-XBOX 360 crosshair in Remastered Edition. Aiming has issues and is not as precise as the OG.
-Some muffled audio sounds in this Remastered Edition. You don't have this issue on the OG.
-No multiplayer modes for the Remastered version.[/b]


[h1]RECOMMENDATION:[/h1]
[b]The graphical downgrade cannot be ignored. It is to wonder why was this game Remastered from the XBOX 360 port? Why didn't they used the PC version and improved upon it? If you get past the visuals, the game is still pretty great. The gameplay/controls is more fluid in my opinion than the original version. If you can't get past the poor visuals, I strongly recommend you get the game on either EA Desktop app or GOG.

I recommend you get this game in great discount or better, get the Trilogy so you can play the better optimized sequels![/b]

Crysis Remastered looks better and runs better than the original games in everyway, especially with the raytracing features turned on. However, due to being made from the PS3/Xbox360 console port instead of the original PC release, the Remastered version has a few shortcomings and missing features but it is not enough to hamper the gameplay experience. 

What does hamper the gameplay experience however was the plethora of new bugs and glitches found in this version that did not exist in the original 2007 release nor the console ports. Although these can be fixed the [b]Crysis Remastered Improvement Project[/b] mod by [b]CallistoNTG[/b], it is disappointing that the game has stopped receiving official updates.

What's more disappointing however is the lack of the multiplayer and full scale mod support that the original got, which offer players a tonnes of replayability and variety of user made content and modes both online and singleplayer. Resulting in an overall short experience that can be completed in under 10 hours without much replayability. I've 100% the game and got all achievements within 9 hours.

Overall, Crysis Remastered looks impressive and play as well as the original, bar the new bugs and glitches. It's a game I can wholeheartedly recommend and well worth experiencing again even if you've played the original. But without the modding capability the original has, Crysis Remastered feels lacking when compared to the 2007 release.

The original Crysis is still not really my jam, but now, on this third or so replay of the game, I finally got to enjoy it a bit. Of all 4 titles in the franchise (so far), it remains the biggest and most ambitious but also most dependent on players dictating their own fun. The levels are gigantic, ways to tackle the problems and accomplish goals are numerous and it’s very easy to try to stick to a gameplay approach that doesn’t work that well with the game. After all, these Crysis isn’t really an immersive sim, even if it’s very close conceptually to a somewhat streamlined resemblance of one, so if you don’t play it as an FPS and try to focus more on stealth or something else, it quickly gets boring or frustrating. But if you do play it as an FPS, enhanced by the nanosuit ability to stealth, run super fast, punch wooden houses apart and have additional protection, if you just use the binoculars to tag enemies and plan your approach but then dynamically adjust to the situation that unfolds, instead of just stealthing or just running, it can get really fun.

Especially since the Remastered version includes the suit modes and controls from the second and third games. I know it’s blasphemous for superfans of the original, but I genuinely think that the simplified suit controls mode is a more fun experience that makes the nanosuit feel far more powerful than it usually is due to the later titles’ armor mode. It doesn’t quite gel with the way the original game worked, of course, since you can’t speed+reload and your sprint is always way too fast (and drains energy), also the strength jumping is very iffy. But going through the game with quick one-button switching feels far more fluid. While the rest of the game is still quite entertaining. Even if I personally preferred the slightly more directed experience of Warhead, that sadly isn’t included in the remaster and seemingly never will be remastered due to the loss of the game source code.

Remaster isn’t without its own flaws either, as it was based on the slightly cut down version of the game made for the consoles after Crysis 2 release, not the 2007 PC original. Numerous updates since release returned some of the details that got lost in this transition, including one whole level of the game that was originally cut, but a lot of smaller and more noticeable details are still gone. Not that the game looks bad – it looks amazing and improves on most things of the original title, while also running far better on modern hardware. But it’s just not a clear win of a remaster. If you haven’t played the original, I’d recommend going for Remastered if you’re in any way interested. The game is more than just pretty visuals, but if you’re not into more sandbox titles, you might not enjoy it a lot.

Crysis 1 has aged like milk. The first half is filled with boring, uninspired semi-sandbox levels you can just sprint through. The second half is linear shooting sections against the same 2 alien types over and over again. Exposition is dumped on you in the last level and then the game abruptly ends. 

Impressive for 2007, Crysis 1's visuals cannot carry it's lackluster shooting. Voice acting is laughably bad, especially from it's side characters. Weapons spurt out flat, tinny noises vaguely resembling a gunshot; throwing objects through certain walls results in a mess of visual bugs and broken physics. The suit noises are still delightful though. How I do enjoy hearing "maximum"...well anything really over and over again. 

As for the remaster fixing performance issues - the addition of DLSS has the game running way better than before. Which is a massive benefit due to how the original Crysis is held together with duck tape and glue. Optimizations have been made across the board, which don't so much fix the longstanding CPU issue, but rather circumvent it. With modern hardware you'll be seeing Crysis 1 for the first time at 144fps+ which is worth any sort of other visual downgrades to the color pallet. It does however, still run noticeably worse than Crysis 2 & 3; despite those games visuals still holding up to modern titles.

First of all before I get started, I would like to state that I, Personally, have never played a Crysis game in my life. This is my first ever experience on Crysis. From what I have read in the reviews for the game... I don't see anyone with some of the issues that I am about to state. Ok, here we go below:

[h1][b] My issues [/b][/h1]
⚫The story feels as if I am being rushed to the end conclusion of the game. Starting out from parachuting down to the island, to having to fight "ALIENS" in less than an hour... 
⚫The maps, which there are a few of them, are Linear focused based maps that are way to bigger than they need to be. There's roughly 8 (I don't know exactly) and they offer no replay value or exploration - I will get to these 2 in a minute. They could have better optimised the game by locking up some of these area's and freeing up some assets.
⚫Now... the exploration in the game is a joke. There is no point in exploring the map at all. There is no collectables, hidden items or anything else you may want to find. I feel let down by this one.
⚫Also... the replay value of this game is also non-existent. I completed the game on DELTA difficulty in under 6 hours. 5.2 hours to be exact. I got 100% of my achievements in one play-through of the game meaning that I don't need to go back to it at all unless I want to play the game again.
⚫The characters and dialogue feel like it has been very badly developed and written. Some of the lines they say in this are just downright cringe. There is a scene in the game where you have to save the scientist woman and she is on the elevator, right. After you join her she jumps to a rope and the elevator starts to fall not even 50ft down and your character almost pass's out but yet at the start of the game you fell from Aeroplane height.... and hit the water with your suit but you came out in PERFECT condition. This feels like the story started with a different writer and then was handed down to a less developed writer.
⚫This last one many might not care about - The game costs £25. It offers No replay-ability. So its a one time deal if you collect all your achievements in one go. No way is this game worth £25 alone. I'm sorry but no.

[h1][b] The Pros [/b][/h1]
⚫I have heard alot of players say that the optimisation on this game is trash... Not once did I personally experience freezing, FPS drops, crashing or anything else.
⚫Its a NEW game for me so I kinda had fun playing it a little.
⚫Its a Remastered version of an "apparently" good game so if you liked the old ones... there you go I suppose.
⚫ The water mechanics in this game are SUPERB. Some of the best I have seen... like no joke.
⚫The bullet tracers are phenomenal as well. You can actually see where you bullets go and where they are coming from. Some games in 2022 cannot even do this right. YES THAT'S RIGHT Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, i'm calling you out.
⚫The game has some form of "levolution destruction" in it. If you do not know what that is, look at Battlefield 4 (mainly). You get to destroy buildings, trees and other small objects like they never existed in the first place.
EDIT: "They have fixed most of the performance issues after Nov 17" I read from someones review... so by the looks of it, it had REALLY bad issues before I got to it. 

[h1][b] All in All  [/b][/h1]
The game is good but with the price and next to no replay-ability on it at all... it is not worth the money in the slightest. I would avoid this until it is around £10 on sale or something like that. 4/10. Sorry but this is my honest to god review from a "BLIND" run.

EDIT #2: I recently got all 3 Crysis Remastered games for £24's roughly in a trilogy bundle so I would recommend buying that instead of getting them separately.

My main gripes with the game are: Who the f* playtests those games? I just can't believe how fast the mouse sensitivity is at the absolute minimum.(at 800dpi) I had to configure the slider myself via an autoexec file to make the mouse feel like it's not on crack.
After fixing the FOV and the sensitivity for the main game - the vehicle aiming is just absolutely unusable. It's WAYYYY too slow. Like I'd use my whole mousepad area for the damn camera in-game to barely move 10 degrees, and playing on DELTA difficulty, it was IMPOSSIBLE to kill those enemies in the sky with the anti-aircraft vehicle or whatever that thing is. I had to get out of it and use other guns to do what I was supposed to do in a vehicle. Like genuinely this makes me question if the devs responsible for the mouse controls even playtested this. Like, did they just make it somewhat work and decided "eh, whatever that's good enough"???
How does the game just go from sonic aiming to turtle mode in vehicles? Can't it just strike a balance somewhere in the middle? Goddamnit.
Second: The performance is...good-ish? But I'd still expect better. On a 3080+Ryzen 9 5900x I was getting about 80-160 fps, perhaps with rare drops into the 70's, that's running max settings, apart from object detail, which was set to high. Running at 1440p with DLSS on quality. 
Graphics: Objectively it looks better in places, the draw distance is better, the lighting is better, the reflections are good. However the faces of characters look really bad here, I'm even going to say they were better in the original. The caves just look terrible here, the volumetric lights are gone. 
Gameplay: The game is easy once you understand what it wants from you, however it doesn't always make sense. It's not fair. Your AR bullets would rarely go where you aim because of bullet spread, so unless you have a gauss rifle or a precision rifle (aka sniper), then you're way better off sneaking up to enemies in cloak mode then killing them. Now this would be okay if only the enemies ALSO had this bullet spread, but no, they can mow me down like they're shooting a fully automatic sniper rifle with no recoil. Sometimes the game would glitch and your cloak wouldn't even work. Like I was cloaked behind cover far away from a tank, I walked all the way to the other side of a road and the second I see the tank I'm dead, WHILE CLOAKED. Other times I can't even see the enemies cause they're on the other side of the map, yet they can see me perfectly fine. This just fucking ruins the "predator" vibe you're supposed to have with that suit (at least on the delta difficulty), because the enemies just have the best eyesight in the world, you hide, cloak walk around them faaaaaar away, the second you uncloak (if you're not in the bushes) you're spotted.

Greatly Remastered.

Overall graphics are adorable. Running on D3D11, which is confusing, but still uses Ray Tracing flawlessly. many textures have been remade, and some of them are just the upscaled old ones. The performance is still a bit weird but it can be solved by turning on DLSS. Particles and effects don't look perfect though, which is a weak point of the graphical part but I still don't blame them since it's just a Remaster (at least a better remaster than the other Cryses with lazy 480p cutscenes). And, insane reflections. On maximum graphics with RT Boost mode enabled, you can notice your own character's reflection on many surfaces, from a slight dark halo of your body shape on rough metal parts, to a full picture of yourself on every glassy surface (Well, to blame the other games on the industry, at least it doesn't use [i]cubemaps[/i] & SSR while their games allegedly has RT support). I think the ugliest part of the game is the character design. Almost every character's eyelids got noticeable problems, they're not textured professionally, and all of them are textured with the upscaled old textures with visible upscaling artifacts. They need to be remade, for sure.

The gameplay has slightly changed (as far as I know). It's still tough to figure out the mechanics and learn the behavior of the enemy and how to deal with it, But it's mostly enjoyable. Still got many parts that make you frustrated, but that's acceptable. 
It has some bugs, but not annoying at all. None of them will affect your gameplay.

And to talk about the actual game, it has a well-made concept with a cool badass alien-invasion-kind-of story. It's really worth it, and it always goes on great discounts, so don't miss it if you have a good PC!

[i]This review is based ONLY on performance of the game on the STEAM DECK.[/i]


[h1]The Game Itself:[/h1]


A simple rescue mission goes haywire in the worst way possible in the remaster for the classic FPS game that defined the benchmark question: "Can it Run Crysis?". In Crysis Remastered, you are armed with your nanosuit and swap between super speed, strength, armor, and cloaking to tackle your enemies in a constantly changing environment. Using your suit and tools, you will need to tackle threats beyond this world and figure out just what the hell is going on.


[h1]Steam Deck Performance:[/h1]


Crysis Remastered has gotten mixed ratings due to a couple reasons. These include bugs, some graphical downgrades from the original, and it being a port from the console releases. Unfortunately, this is the only way to play the original Crysis unless you owned the original before it was delisted from Steam. The good news is, it plays quite well!

I started off at the medium settings and was pleasantly surprised how well it ran. For the most part, it could stick to 45 FPS without any caps, but the battery would drain a bit more than I would like during some high octane parts of gameplay like driving into an explosion, tons of enemies on screen shooting, and sprinting across the world. I decided for a recommended initial build to stick to 40 FPS with some settings lowered to "low" for stability purposes. I also lowered resolution to 1152x720 as this drastically helped during those intense moments.

Crysis Remastered also supports simultaneous KB+M and Gamepad inputs at the same time, which means enabling gyro controls through Steam Input will work well! I have found setting the gyro behavior to mouse feels a bit better, but setting to joystick works too.

For the full review, I will provide 2 other builds that will make improvements to battery and a higher framerate, but due to Crysis Remastered being a large game, I want to test more before making those recommendations. I didn't encounter any major bugs that were specifically due to the Steam Deck and overall I felt the game ran without a hitch. I did blow up many houses and tried to instigate a lot of physics movements, but it held strong. I have been pleasantly surprised so far how well it is running and feeling, especially coming from how hard it was to run the original.

In the half-hour or so that I spent playing, I encountered numerous bugs and deficits that made the game too frustrating to play given that I can play the original any time without dealing with those issues.

A few examples:
[list]
[*]Trying to "sprint" while prone just makes your character stand up, rather than causing them to crawl faster like in the original game
[*]Playing with classic suit controls + suit shortcuts straight up doesn't work, the shortcut keybinds do nothing when pressed
[*]Changing the HUD color setting has almost no effect; it makes maybe 80% of the menu screen change to your chosen color, and has no effect on the in-game HUD
[*]The footstep sound when using armor mode (which will generally be the case) makes it sound like you're 3x heavier and made of stone, it sounds obnoxious and makes no sense, why is it a thing...
[*]At least in the very beginning of the game (the part I got to see before refunding), the visuals are either similar to or worse than the original. Character skin looks worse, clouds look worse, and the nanosuit vaporization effect in the second cutscene is almost entirely missing. Most other visual elements didn't look noticeably better than using a modded version of the original game.
[/list]
I know that in areas that are indirectly lit (interior spaces, shaded areas) the lighting is massively ahead of the original, and transparent and reflective surfaces must look better too. But I didn't get to see any of that before I quit, so I can't give my impression. All I know is it doesn't make up for the cost of buying the game, especially in light of all the bugs and other frustrating elements that dragged the game down considerably from the original.

If after watching the Digital Foundry videos on this game you're not bothered by the shortcomings they list, nor bothered by any of the ones I shared above, then sure, it might be worth getting if it's on sale for 50% off or more. But I personally wouldn't recommend spending any more than $5 unless they significantly improve the game via patches, which seems unlikely at this point.

Crysis is a fun, pretty game that ultimately doesn't deliver on the initial promise of its first levels. It's still worth playing, even if it's just to experience the entertaining nanosuit abilities and marvel at what was, and is, a very good-looking game.

The first few levels are these big open environments that give you freedom in how you approach their objectives. But this is only true in the most literal sense; you can approach the objectives from any direction, because you aren't boxed into a linear path. But that's where that freedom ends; there aren't any options in terms of how you actually complete the tasks set for you, or any "immersive sim" style gameplay choices.

After these early levels, the game becomes much more of a linear shooter. It's still entertaining, but it's probably not what you came for, or expected.

Playing on the hardest mode, the game is mostly weirdly easy, with very generous health and shield recovery and plenty of ammo available. The nanosuit's ability to make you super strong, invisible, or really fast mean you can easily out manoeuvre enemies and any challenge really just comes from making sure you get the first shot on any enemy you encounter.

The biggest disappointment I have with Crysis is that most of the weapons are boring to shoot. There's this great system where you can modify weapon attachments on the fly, but you never really get a truly exciting weapon, with the possible exception of the missile launcher (when is a missile launcher ever not fun?)

This remaster is mostly fine, though there are some pretty severe audio balancing issues, and moments where sound effects or music aren't audible when they should be. Vehicles that are hundreds of metres away sound like they're right on top of you, weird stuff like that. This version of the game also uses a checkpoint system with no manual saving, which is a really poor substitute.

It's a recommend with several caveats, but I did have a good time for the most part. Something about the suit announcing "Cloak. Engaged." triggers a dopamine release for me, so that alone was worth the price of admission!

I see the appeal, but overall don't think this game holds up anymore.

The good:

* Overall, the game is very ambitious. The huge island, the setpieces, the detailed per-component damage of vehicles, the binoculars, etc. There's a lot they didn't *need* to do, but showed a lot of interesting ideas.

The bad:

* Audio mixing and audio in general. It was frequently hard to hear dialogue, there were sound effects way out of volume proportionally, there were some sounds that "stuck around" too long, etc. Most pathetic shotgun sound I've ever heard too. The alien weapon sounds like shooting peas through a straw. 

* The gun play is awful. Judged by modern standards, it just feels so bad to shoot in this game. Weapons are inaccurate and enemies are spongy. It's just so frustrating and unfun to use most of the weapons, with very few exceptions. (The minigun and rocket launcher are pretty OK)

* Pretends to be an open game, but you really have very specific objectives to do in a specific order. There's no reason to explore the island at all, so it's really more a cool idea than a feature.

* Vehicle controls and weapon aiming are so bad it made me want to quit at the tank level. It's horrible.

* Suit's power level is so limited, cloaking or speed last for all of a couple seconds. You don't really "weave" your abilities together naturally. You just use the armor ability and wait for it to recharge when it's out. Speed sort of helps navigating between objectives, but it's very limited as stated earlier.

* Some of the voice acting is OK, but there's a lot that's quite mediocre as well. Between that and the awful facial animations, the story can be cringy and painful at parts.

* Still a few bugs. Seems most of them have been fixed, but I got stuck inside a crashed Vtol which was very un-fun.

* Fairly short. I got through it in 5 hours. I didn't intend to speedrun, but the gunplay and vehicles were so painful that I rushed around to avoid those as much as possible.

Final thoughts:

Maybe this was considered a better game back in '07, but as a modern game it just doesn't hold up at all IMO.

A remaster is supposed to fix problems that the old game had and maybe improve on mechanics and graphics. While mechanics and graphics didn't change much (which some things should've been added, like an option to turn off toggle aim), I can tell you right now that this remaster added more issues than it fixed.

I played and finished the game on Delta difficulty and the first part of the game where you fight the Koreans was pretty much the same as the first Crysis. No problems and the gunplay was good.

However, when it came time to fight the [spoiler] aliens [/spoiler] , boy oh boy did the problems start cropping up.

The first major issue I encountered was during the missions where you [spoiler] fly the VTOL. [/spoiler] The vehicle would not respond to my mouse at all. Keyboard commands worked just fine but I couldn't actually control where the vehicle was looking. My solution to this was to plug in a controller I had nearby. This worked fine, but because I had played 70% of the game up to that point, my precision in using the vehicle was horrendous and I missed out on several secondary objectives while completing the mission. 

The other major issue I encountered was the final boss fight:
[spoiler] I thought I was going to have an aneurysm doing this boss fight. There is a nice ammo stockpile so you can reload your strongest weapons, but the 70% of the ship is on fire, including the stockpile. The fire doesn't even correspond to where you take damage. I could be meters away and still be taking damage from the fire. Also, if you're not in cover, there's a good chance the boss will spot you through stealth and freeze you until you die, so that's really fun. Also, my TAC Cannon didn't even work half the time. I'd lock on and fire the projectile, only for it to clip through the boss. [/spoiler] 

At the end of the game, I didn't even get the achievements for completing the game, but that could just be because I skipped the credits, but I'm definitely not going back to get them.

Overall, just play the original Crysis. Here's to hoping those good reviews about Crysis 2 and 3 Remastered are true.

I'll be as honest as I can with this Crysis 1 "Remaster"

I'm brand new to Crysis, never having had the ability to run these games when they were in their prime, back circa 2007 or whatever. I've since bought the original Crysis 1 after this remaster made me puke blood.

So naturally, anyone new to the series who's buying this version of Crysis 1 for the first time would probably think: "Well, I've never played the original so I might like the remaster purely for what it is, despite it's many claimed differences".

Wrong.
You're going to shoot yourself in the foot if you approach this Remaster with that attitude, and you ain't going to have no nanosuit to protect those toes either. 

Allow me to begin:

(1) The "volumetric clouds" look like silly bubbles.

(2) The sky is so blue that it makes me feel like I'm in Bikini Bottom from Spongebob.

(3) The grass is a saturated cartoon green that makes me feel as if someone tried to put me in a jar with a leaf so that they could attempt to mimic my human environment for me.

(4) My "3080Ti Mobile" flings the fps counter from 90 down to 45 in two person gun fights, showing some very poor optimization that shouldn't be evident in a game this old. 

The pain doesn't stop there, I promise. This version is essentially the pc version, ported to console with downgrades, then ported back again from console back to PC with "enhancements". Lies, all lies.

The old version of Crysis 1, which has since been removed from Steam, never really was the way to go either. Steam's original version was 32bit only, making it a avoidable version at best.

Just avoid this, unless you like Fortnite or something.
