Can it run Crysis, the term has been renewed. That is the short version.
Considering this is a remaster, not an entire remake. It will on that setting, demand an RTX 3080 or better to run, at least in 4k.

The original was released in 2007, running the second iteration of CryEngine.
A piece of gaming history.

What has changed, considering it's a remaster it still uses the original game's assets. Like all remasters do.
What has been added:
*Higher Draw Distance LOD, would be the most noticeable.
*Completely new lighting techniques, including Ray Tracing. Your GPU doesn't even need to support it, it's built into the engine itself. While the game offers some basic extension to it, turned on by a simple checkbox.
*Tesselation on more objects such as rocks, mainly is where you will notice it.
*Texture resolution on assets, some are even remodeled from scratch.
*Sound samples, mainly on guns and they way they sound.
* Ray Tracing light effects, you can run this effect in this game even without an RTX enabled GPU. It's embedded in the engine's software according to Linus Tech. Also here the minuses begin, it's demanding. A lot!
* Quality of Life improvements to the controls. The control scheme is taken from Crysis 2 and 3, and gives you easier access to the nano suit. However if you preferred the original game's controls, you can still go back to that. Other QoL stuff is the intuitive toggle function on certain actions such as aim down sight and crouch. The original game locked ADS to toggle and crouch to hold and you could not change that. This point is probably the only reason I would recommend the remaster over the original. That and this remaster IS very good looking if you can afford to turn up the graphics settings.

-Shaders, makes the game look like a cartoon. It's not celshading thankfully. Everything is just too green, too lush. Where the original showed moonlight on the palm leaves, here they simply look... unreal. You can easily mod this however.
-HDR, but absolutely gives nothing for it. We're not talking anything remotely HDR10 here. It's like they forgot that HDR supports 10bit color depth but all the assets are still 8bit. Games that supports W11 HDR enhancement looks better using it than this game does with official HDR support.
-Again Texture resolution, apparently or obviously resolution doesn't always mean sharper. Some look even worse than the original, like parts of trees, even the nano suits in some places like the helmet. Faces of the main characters? Generic NPC's look better now than the main cast of the game.
-Shadows, they simply shimmer all over the place now a lot of the time. Most likely to the in game Ray Tracing lighting. When it works, it looks great, but it often does not.
-Vegetation, as beautiful it looks on picture, once you're in the game you may notice how static they are. Trees and brushes no longer moves in the wind, no longer do you or NPC displace vegetation in the same realistic manner, nor does the brushwork hide you effectively as they did in the original game.
Also the animations on them seem to be locked at a very low frame rate whenever displacement does occur.

Game does support DLSS! For those with an nVidia card who wants to enjoy this title in 4k. You will need that turned on. Or simply install the original and run it in 4k with ease. It demands about 4GB V-RAM (Which is one of those reasons it never ran well at all on older machines when the original came out, most cards sported about 256-512MB at best back then, but then the target resolution was 1024x768, not even 1920x1080 widescreen, 4k was a dream far far away nobody had probably even thought of being a possibility in video gaming back then)
The original Crysis runs very well on modern machines from the last 6 years or so. A GTX 1080 can run it in 4k. This remaster however, not so much.

I was running this remaster with an RTX 3080, on an Intel machine 10th Gen i9 10900k, 32 GB of DDR4 RAM at 3000MHz XMP and from an M.2 Drive. Still PCI-X gen 3.0 but... on "Can it run Crysis" settings with DLSS on Quality I get about 40-50 frames per second, in 4k. A stable 60 if I run on Very High. With experimental RTX effects and HDR turned on. This for comparison is about the same I get from Cyberpunk 2077 with Ray tracing turned on and reflections on Psycho and with DLSS on Auto. (Not Quality setting for DLSS it becomes unplayable in 4k for some reason on nVidia cards now when everything else is maxed out, except maybe on a 4090 and is thus the pinnacle on hardware demanding PC games currently, despite even this remasters release trying to clearly be mainly intended to take that back) Either way I guess it's safe to say my machine can run Crysis =)

The best part of this release however, it's an EA owned IP, but doesn't require neither Origin nor EA Play third party applications or accounts to run. It does blow a bit of fresh air into an old but fondly remembered title that is indeed a very important part of PC Gaming History.

Crysis. A title that pushed boundaries of video game fidelity, in fact CryTek, just like Epic has always been about that and the simplicity to use their engines for video game creation. This particular title was definitely a big reason why other video games started looking much better than before. It was and still is a great showcase what games can look like, and I mean even games made today! 13 years later. This version, is sadly a bit generic. Adds things you will most likely not notice all that much, unless you run a comparison of them next to each other. If you want a showcase of RTX effects, even Minecraft and Quake II RTX does a much better job of doing that, or I recommend Cyberpunk 2077 or Watch Dogs Legion to best enjoy that as a tech demonstration.

I would buy this remaster only for the Benchmark, "Can it run Crysis" hence the other title comparisons, and the Steam Achievements. Otherwise, the original release will do you just as well.

You should also know there are MASSIVE differences in the game play when using the sequels mechanics. They were better the first time around I felt, even if they caused you to think before you acted more.
Also the AI is MUCH better at spotting you in the remastered version, even on Delta, making the game immensely harder than the original release.
And last but not least, the original did not use checkpoints or constrain you to to them, the original uses the old fashioned manual saving system and relied on that. The remaster does not offer this, it is a MUCH harder game than the original in comparison. Even on easier difficulties.

Another last minute negative thing: The expansion for the original, Warhead, is NOT included in this release.
Though Warhead was also standalone, you do not need the original game to play it.

A different take for the original Nanosuit system. It's good fun. A little overpriced I feel, but I do recommend getting it on discount. 

Differences (aside from graphics, obv): 
1. The biggest difference is there's no manual save, only checkpoints. I'm playing on delta and hardly noticed any difference, honestly, not a lot of difficulty increase. 
2. Nanosuit. You CAN switch back to the original, but if you played the original, the new system offers some different experiences. 
    2.1: Your energy regens A LOT faster. This makes the "cloak - regen - cloak" loop a lot faster. 
    2.2: Sprinting in speed mode costs MUCH LESS energy. 
    2.3: Jumping in strength mode costs less energy. 
    2.4: Armor mode is completely useless. Not only does it bleeds energy, it costs pretty much the same amount of energy as the original when shot, which was the default mode in the original... So in total it tanks LESS shots cuz of the bleeding. 
    2.5: Your default mode is strength, meaning you don't get the passive protection like in the original, and might get one-shotted more often. 
    2.6: The new strength mode doesn't seem to suppress gun recoil. 

I really like that you activate modes with one button instead of the wheel. I just hope armor mode was still the default mode, unlike the garbage it is now. But oh well, it's still fun. 
Other than that, gameplay wise it's pretty much the same as the original, crouching around in cloak and shooting stuff.

All this game did was make me appreciate the original from 2007 more. For a remaster released in 2020+, this version is a little underwhelming. Textures, water effects, particle effects, depth of field -- sure, all of these things have improvements for the most part. But when you compare side by side, the improvements feel kind of minor, which only speaks to just how good the original already looked to begin with.

To ensure I was getting the most out of this, I enabled the "Can It Run Crysis?" mode with the raytracing enabled, which cranks everything to the max. On my watercooled rig (5950x CPU + 3090 GPU + 64 GB RAM), in 1440p mode with VSync enabled, on a 144 Hz monitor -- framerates usually hovered in the 120 FPS range with some dips going under 100 during heavier scenes, and otherwise capping at 144 when not much was happening. It also pushed my coolant temps to 37C, which is the highest I've ever seen it go (for context, most games barely push it north of 30-31C. Harsher games might put it to 33C or even 35C).

Still very playable, but it's strange to see a remastered version of Crysis that 1. still looks dated by today's standards with little improvement over the original, even with maxed settings, and 2. is way harder on my machine than several modern titles that look better and perform more efficiently.

Pros:

Cons:
The manual save system is completely removed. It has checkpoint saves only and you can't choose to go back to specific checkpoints either...your only options are the most recent checkpoint or the beginning of the level and that's it.
Every time I start the game back up, that dastardly motion blur setting is back on again no matter how many times I turn it off.
While some of the sound effects have been improved (starting rifle and the pistol for example), some are just as bad as they were before (the fictional AK sounds unchanged) however some are significantly worse...the footsteps, even when walking on grass or sand sound like you have giant metal boots and are moving on a metal floor...even when sneaking softly.
To use the suit quickwheel menu like the old game, you enable this in the gameplay settings. When you are crouching down and access this wheel, it causes you to stand up for no reason. So hiding behind something and accessing this wheel to cloak means standing up and being seen, defeating the purpose of cloaking because now you need armor mode and are in a fire fight. If you disable this classic wheel mode, you are either in armor or strength mode and just manually enable cloak when needed. However, when you run, it auto uses speed mode! What, why!? I don't want to use speed mode every single time. That should be its own separate setting in my opinion.
I think the stealth is off...I used to be able to crouch and hide in bushes/shrubs or prone crawl in high grass until fairly close to an enemy, causing them to get surprised. Now I can sit perfectly still in some bushes and the enemies see me from a pretty good distance away. Crysis 2 and 3 had that issue where stealth was REALLY bad so I'm guessing they maybe used a newer Crytek engine from one of those games to make this one and weren't able to replicate the awesome quality stealth that the original had.
The game is horribly optimized.

Optimization deserves its own section:
I'm no fool, I get that the highest settings are often designed for screenshots and to attract gamers. It gives us something to upgrade for, gives us something to compare to, gives us something to benchmark etc. So typically if I can't max a game I lower stuff one setting at a time as needed and eventually play it smoothly. My system currently is an i9-12900k, 3090ti and 32GBs of DDR5 running windows 10 on a gen 5 (EDIT: oops gen 4 not 5) PCIe NVMe. Theoretically it should be strong enough for everything I can throw at it since I am only running a 1440p ultrawide, not a 4K but still, the max settings were aimed at being future proof such as with the original game so I began tweaking the usual suspects like ray tracing and shadows etc without being annoyed. I got to the coastal house of level 1 (when the sun is up and the jet flies by) and disabled v-sync so I could begin troubleshooting. I ended up basically lowering EVERYTHING to low and it still didn't feel smooth and playable. There is one setting however (Objects Quality) that can't be changed in game so I went back to the main menu to change it. After it lagged on 'Can it Run Crysis' I tried 'Very High' and then 'High.' It started to feel better on 'Medium' but didn't feel smooth until 'Low.' You have got to be kidding me. It seriously either lagged hardcore or felt like my walk speed was varying in speed as I moved along with anything above 'Low.' Never seen a single setting so badly optimized. Isn't a dealbreaker by itself but really odd.

Long story short - I think this was a huge disappointment and can't recommend it to anyone that played the original.
If you did NOT play the original then this one is probably a better choice since the original is also horribly optimized but also struggles in other ways on modern systems.

With the release of Crysis in 2007, Crytek raised the bar on graphics to heights that many other titles could not. The game (for that time) could boast not only excellent graphics, but also destructible environments, good voice acting and immersiveness. The player immersed himself in the game and, together with the hero, thought out his way to the point of the task - through the Jungle filled with Koreans.
In 2020, Crytek decided to play on the feelings of the players and just released the same game again. Only slightly improving the graphics in some places - adding a newfangled rtx. Which, instead of making an already great game even more colorful, did the opposite.
With the advent of rtx in the world of Crysis, the surrounding space became bright, pale and lost most of the shadows. In addition, Crytek has significantly degraded most of the textures. Because of what it is already impossible to look at the faces of the heroes without a shudder.
I sincerely believe that Crytek wanted to make the game better - but simply loading the game with new technologies is not the same as improving it. 
Due to the changes, the game has become hundreds of times easier, losing the former challenge that the original threw.
I do not recommend this game. Especially if you have not played the original, then I advise you to buy it easier than this remaster.

I don't understand why they went with alien invasion in the second half of the game. The game mechanics work much better with the infiltration type of game in the first half. Also what's wrong with the weapons; they don't seem to carry any punch. The alien gattling gun sounds like a snowball gun - Wtf. Graphics look still incredible, especially regarding the age of the game. Story is way more boring and full of flat male and curvy female characters - if you catch my drift. Would still recommend. The boss fight at the end is simply the worst and comically/"consolically" boring (shoot the shiny piece - now evade - then shoot the other shiny piece - the end).

Crysis Remastered is really not worth the money nor the hype it originally received. When I saw this game and hear the original reviews for it I was all well and good to ignore any negative criticism and just try the game out to see its 'quality' for myself, But personally I don't believe Crysis Remastered really adds a whole lot to improve to the original game and the graphical 'improvements' aside the only really noticeable additions this remaster really makes is with the enemy AI, but even that is a laughable claim. I also experienced painful issues with the view models and collision models of objects not lining up correctly, with the case often being that i'd shoot at an enemy that is in view but the shot will not connect because it hit the 'rock'. I have also encountered many other bugs such as: weird water effects appearing on boats that are completely out of water, odd water effects on boats sitting in water, enemies that are very large distances away sounding as if they are 5 metres from my face, odd bullet physics with bullets landing far above where they are shot, and other weird physics related bugs with cars and debris. So in conclusion if you are looking to play Crysis but the original and if the graphics really concern you that much slap on a few community made mods and you'll have a similar but more refined experience than what Crysis Remasterd can offer.

Side Note: The water caustics do look quite nice though, so at least that's something nice

Started off loving it! It brought back great memories, it looked awesome and played much better than the original, but in the end I can't say that this version is worth it.

Getting the positives out of the way; the game is loads of fun to play, looks way more detailed ([i]in some areas[/i]) than the original and you can play the game on maxed graphics without frame issues ([i]at least to some degree[/i]).

If you played the original from 2007, maybe you would be enticed to get a copy of this game. Fortunately for me, it was on a massive sale and I decided to give this a shot since I haven't played the game in years. I was impressed by the detail and how well things were running, up until they weren't.

Although the graphics look awesome, the game is still poorly optimised and you'll notice it particularly in some areas where there's lots of water. Raytracing isn't really worth it as well, but you especially need to lower object detail to medium to get better frames. In fact, everything on medium looks pretty good, so just play on that for better frames.

The worst part though is the amount of model glitches and poor controls. Mouse sensitivity was way too fast and I had to adjust my mouse DPI. Keybindings are just crap. I play ESDF style so naturally that'll include my tank and VTOL. It doesn't respond at all and I was forced to use WSDF on these missions, not a game breaker... at least not until the VTOL mission.

[b]This is where things get really f***ed up and what made me give this game a negative review[/b]. Mouse controls on this mission don't work at all! I've read forums or guides and nobody seems to have a solution that I saw. Your only option is to plug in a controller, which I had, but it was an awful experience. I got incredibly frustrated during this mission and it made me wonder what was the point of remastering a pretty damn good game and then you mess up so many things, especially the controls. It just appears to be grabbing a quick buck and ruining the memory of a great game, I don't understand this logic, but it's becoming far too common nowadays!

You're better off playing the 2007 version. It works, it still looks great and it doesn't have half of the problems the remastered version has.

If you're like me who got it on a very good deal, then sure, pick up a copy. I got all of the achievements in one single run, so that was pretty cool, but make sure to get a controller as well, since you won't be able to beat the VTOL mission without it.

It's an improvement only, not evolution - so it's kinda mixed bag, especially that Crysis was always the game with leading, astonishing graphics.

The AI in this remaster are broken; they are straight out of Far Cry 1 and will instantly spot you when you're uncloaked but fully behind cover. 

Speaking of cloaking, you cannot use the classic nanosuit middle mouse control while crouched; you'll just stand up if you try, which is counter-productive and has gotten me spotted.

Pressing spacebar is how you get up from prone in Classic, but in this remaster you actually JUMP INTO THE AIR from the prone position, which is also counter-productive and has gotten me spotted.

Switching grenade types in Classic does not equip the grenade, you keep whatever is in your hands; in the remaster, switching grenade type puts the grenades into your hands, which has gotten me killed.

Most of the "rethought" controls are nonsensical and directly conflict with the flow of the game. 

You can't even manually save your progress like you could in Classic, you just have to deal with autosave points. The only noticeable improvements in this remaster are higher texture resolutions, greater draw distance, parallax occlusion mapping, and tessellation. 

If you can find a cd key somewhere for the original Crysis, just get that and look up the advanced launch options to run it on multicore rigs. Classic still looks absolutely fantastic and mods take it to the next level.

I'm going to break this game down into three parts. There will be spoilers ahead but this game has been out since the early 2000's so most people should know what the story is by this point. 

The Good:

- This game functions as a perfectly fine FPS. It does exactly what it says on the tin. The integration of the nano suit makes combat with the game varied enough so that it doesn't feel like your typical Modern Warfare/Battlefield game play loop. 

- The environments and the design of the game from a visual stance is nice to see. The jungles feel very dense with different areas that can be used for tactical use such as hiding or cover when needed. The way that enemy strong points gave access to different approaches of combat was also refreshing. The visuals themselves, while I don't have a rig that can run the game at maximum settings, was very pretty and you could tell why this game pushed graphical boundaries to not only their limit but even made new ones. 

- The difficulties paired with enemy A.I. felt reasonable. I played the game at medium difficulty because if I wanted to play a difficult game, I would go play Dark Souls. This I wanted to be more of a fun and relaxing, unwinding experience. 

- Weapon variety is nice and there are certain combinations for almost every player type. If you want to go stealth or extremely aggressive or something in between there are plenty of options to choose from. 

The Bad:

- The story and the characters are a mayonnaise sandwich. While the nano suit is a very nice addition to the game, the actual game play loop is uninspiring and lacks a lot of creative impact or direction. This game feels like it's selling points was the nano suit and how amazing the graphics could look if you had the insane hardware requirements needed in order to do so. 

- While the environment is nice to look at and game in, it does get repetitive after a while. I really wish there were more areas to use and plan your mode of attack through instead of just a enemy encampment or dense jungle. There are a few select areas that do change it up slightly, one being in the alien ship where you had to align yourself correctly while floating in zero gravity and enemies could come from any angle. but other than that, attention to include environmental combat and having a wider ecosystem to fight in would have been fantastic to see. 

- Maybe it was just my experience, but there were times I would pick up a weapon that had it's flashlight on or there was mention that I had the option to use different ammo types or an under-slung weapon system. It didn't matter what I pressed there was no way to use any of these options or turn the flashlight off. 

- The inclusion of the nano suit was nice, but a lot of the times I just opted to use one feature of the suit for a huge chunk of my play-through. The sprinting feature was the only other option I used. I think if the game had been designed around the suit and the features it included would have brought the game head and shoulders where it is now. 

The Ugly

- This game is horrifically buggy. The A.I. would act up and not function properly. There were swathes of the game that I couldn't interact with anything or a prompt wouldn't appear and I would wonder around gormless until I had to look up what I was supposed to do next. Events that characters in the game would exclaim and point out never actually appeared on screen and I just had to use my imagination of what could or might have happened.  

- There is no reason to use any of the features the nano suit provides instead of its invisibility feature. Pair that with any weapon with a sight and you can breeze through most if not all of the game in no time. Paired with the buggy A.I. and it makes the game play even less interesting. 

- I had to stop playing the game because the second part of the final boss fight I could not get through. Not because it was difficult, but because I was caught in an endless loop of the alien mother ship freezing me over and over, which you have to spend time breaking out of, while the smaller alien ships around it would endlessly hit me and I would just die with no way out of it. I tried every tactic I could think of and nothing worked. 

- There are plenty of times where whatever I was shooting at, the bullets would just phase through the target. This is especially frustrating during the final boss fight where you need to hit certain points on the mother ship and your bullets would just go right through it and cause absolutely no damage. 

- The story and the characters bore me to tears. You're not invested in anything that happens on the island because everything has the same impact and depth as rice paper. Enemy units start employing their own type of nano suits? No further investigation into that, it just gets brought up once and never mentioned again. You discover alien life and that the strange structures around the island belong to an advance alien race and the island is sheltering a huge alien ship? Your character barely comments on any of this. The game put all of it's eggs into the graphics and hoped you didn't pay attention to anything else. 

- I would not buy this game and because of the experience I had I will not be buying any of its future installments either.

Crysis rates as my favorite FPS game out there. The original game is known for its graphics and I believe the remaster looks great in most respects. When I first saw the trailer for the remaster, I was not too big a fan of some of the changes made especially in regards to the color and saturation of the environment. However, playing it for sometime, the changes have grown on me. Plus, I think the new textures look great especially the beach and rock textures. The ray-tracing is great too, it is really cool to see Nomad's reflection for one, and I think the lighting of the environments is very well done in this remaster. And that to me seems a huge improvement over the original, which still looked good in that regard. So overall I like the remaster from a visual standpoint. I've always enjoyed the gameplay in Crysis, especially in the first 2/3 of the game. The levels are very large and allow for a lot of freedom in approaching objectives, despite the game technically being a linear one, at least in regards to the story. The last third falls a bit in quality in my opinion when encountering the alien enemies. To me, those levels don't feel as well designed and too linear compared to the earlier chapters. But they do offer some variety and a change of pace with battling the alien enemies, which I think are pretty cool and well done. I'd say the only level I really dislike is the final one, in particular the final boss fight, which I find frustrating and not all that creative. I'd say that the story is fairly straightforward and the characters too, but I think that fits the game just fine. The nanosuit is a ton of fun to use. The different modes add to the variety of choice in this game. Cloak for stealthy runs then strength and speed for rushing in and grabbing and tossing enemies is always great too. Compared to the later entries in the Crysis trilogy I prefer the feeling of the strength and speed in this game. The strength jumps and punches truly seem super strong. And the speed sprint truly seems fast. As far as changes in the remaster I believe a lot of issues were patched since release. I did not own the game at that point as I didn't have the hardware, but now that I do it runs great overall. One gripe is that option to save at any point has been removed as compared to the original game. It is not that big of a deal, as the checkpoint system I think works well enough, but that feature is lacking. Another change I noticed is on the Onslaught (tank) level that the tank can now fire infinite shells. In the original Crysis on PC the tank shells were limited, making that level a little more difficult. Besides that, sometimes the enemy AI seems to me to pick up Nomad in cloak a little easier compared to the original Crysis, but that is just my observation and I could be wrong. Now that I have the hardware to run this remaster I am overall really happy with it from the gameplay to the new visuals.

So, after playing and finishing this, I just realized that Crysis is honestly lame game. Not just this remaster, but the game in general. And I've finished it 4-5 times at least since it got out. 2007 I was super impressed and obsessed by this game, but 15 years later now and I've changed my mind.

Game is super short (it should have at least 10 more levels, because you can literally finish some in few minutes), AI is terrible (this is not just remaster issue, game has been known forever to have shitty AI), not much variety with weapons, enemy variety is lackluster (korean soldiers, nano suit variant, 1 small alien variant, 1 medium alien variant and big boss at the end, that's literally it!), it seems open but it's linear (I don't mind linearity, but with this game it should have been more), story and characters are super generic with nothing to grab you and hold your attention.

The only semi-good thing I would give it is the nanosuit, its voice and badass design and functions. And of course the visuals still hold up to this day (even though remaster has made it shittier).

This remaster is a greedy one. Apart from the fact that it's the very same game we played 14 years ago it has ridiculously high system requirements (again!), glitchy AI, sudden FPS drops from 60-70 on very high settings down to 30-35 with no visible reason, a whole bunch of smaller bugs. Heck, it even misses some effects from the original game. Overall it looks a bit more "cartoonish" than the game from the 2007 and the difficulty sometimes jumps to the souls-like level. Keeping in mind that you have no manual saves it may ruin your day sometimes. And, most importantly, the game as already mentioned by the majority of people here in the feedback section - still uses only 2 CPU cores/4 threads! At the age of multi-core CPUs and threadrippers it's simply laughable! I tried searching the web for some cpu fix but no luck so far. Seems like it's the cry engine hardcoded flaw that cannot be fixed.
Buy only with a huge discount, or simply install the original crysis with mods - thankfully, it has plenty.

I never played the original Crysis so I picked this up. Here's what I can say. If the original Crysis wasn't a technological marvel with its graphics, then I'm sure as hell that it wouldn't have been on anyone's radar. Behind that eye candy is an FPS that's mediocre AT BEST. There's a story to be told but the game doesn't tell it. instead the game has you going from point A to point B without any proper explanation of whatever the fuck is going on. Additionally, the open world setting does absolutely nothing except making the process of moving from one objective to another an absolute hassle. Finally, the biggest issue of this game is the absolute horse shit AI that can spot you from miles away. The AI makes stealth in this game more of a chore, as more of then than not, no matter how careful you plan your approach, the chances of some AI detecting you from 100 fucking feet away is always high. Even when you're hidden the enemies will sometimes just randomly detect you for no good reason leading to inevitable combat. Which brings me to the combat, which is shit smeared ass cheeks. Enemies are HP sponges and they're able to soak up your bullets without even flinching. Did I also mention that there's literally a mission where aiming with the mouse doesn't work (search for Crysis Remastered Ascension mouse not working.) I could go on and on but the verdict is this: the only thing that aged well in Crysis for both the original and Remastered version is the graphics. Don't bother picking this up if you're after an enjoyable FPS Game.

The controls for both controller and kb/m feel too clunky, the performance is not that great (I thought they fixed taht but I guess not), the guns feel weak against human enemies (also headshots are very inconsistent), the game's open world feels too gimmicky since there's almost nothing in between objectives except for maybe an enemy patrol or two, and the suit drains your energy way too fast which is annoying because you're mainly going to use super speed to reach your objectives. 

I find Crysis 2 to be the better game because that game's performance is far better, the levels may have been more linear but it still gave you freedom to approach those levels any way you preferred (like the Halo games except now you can also use stealth), the controls felt great and the game made you feel like an action hero when fighting against humans but then became challenging when you had to fight against the aliens.

Game still holds up as a really good time. The game is still very pretty and lets you tackle a mission however you decide you want to, be it by stealth or guns blazing. Though, with this one having no multiplayer and a roughly 6 hour campaign, I would recommend picking it up on sale like I did.

- Sensitivity in the gunner seat of vehicles is ungodly low. Even at max (sensitivity in game) it is super slow. Increase your mouse to about 3000 dpi and you can destroy anything in your path. 
-grenade changing is weird. Nothing wrong with it just weird. 
- you can drive the tank all the way to the end of the onslaught level. (good thing)
- that bug where you could put like 100000 bullets into a guy and they dont die until you get within arms length of them is fixed (good thing)
- I'm surprised that they kept the "suit shortcuts" setting. (good thing)
- sometimes the sound would cutout (like explosions would make no noise) or play continuously (like gunfire would play but no one would be shooting). 
- Cant pick up a few of the items. Example; in the original, you could pick up rocks, sticks, branches and crates. Everything was intractable. In this version you cant pick up any of those items, but they are still animated in the world. Not a big deal but weird that they'd remove being able to pick up these items but keep them looking like pickup-able items.
- ai is retarded. Lots of enemies walk around with no weapon or spawn without one and pretend to shoot at you. Also had an occasions where the enemy would spawn outside their vehicle (like a tank in onslaught or AAA gun in assault) and just do nothing. 
- No grenade launcher indicator. y'know when you have the grenade launcher attachment and you hold mouse 1 it gives a reticle to aim at. Yeah that was removed. 
-occasionally my controls would mess up where I could not do most of the key functions. I could only shoot and use wasd. 
- that one flying frog glitch when you pick up a frog and throw it straight up and it would fly away. I know its considered a bug but I thought the devs would have kept it as a joke or something. 
- the pistol sounds different in single fire but if you switch it to double round burst it sounds like the original pistol. It's sort of the case with most guns and their firing mode. 
- on the relic level, when approaching the graveyard in a vehicle, you can't. in the original you could drive a vehicle into the graveyard and gun down the nanosuit enemies. But in this version, the tree that you could just drive under now completely stops you.
- cant hold crouch and open your suit radial menu at the same time. BUT if you tap the crouch button THEN open the suit menu, you stay crouched. 
- no cold on guns in the paradise lost level. What I mean is; in the original when you get to that level the guns would be frozen over and the red dot is also clear as day where in the original it was frozen over and near useless. 
- There was no feeling of environment change. In the first level when you see the sunrise the world is completely bright. The point of that in the original (I assumed) was to show off the lighting affects the engine was capable of. This game felt like cl_fullbright was on at times it should have been.
- in the last level there are a few npcs you can push around. If you move them into cut scenes they can make the cut scene 10x better
- "funny how the older version of the cry engine almost seems better than the current." is a thought that crossed my mind

Crysis: Remastered is a sci-fi futuristic first-person shooter developed and published by Crytek and released on Steam in September 2021. I will note I finished Crysis: Remastered last weekend, before Patch 3 was released this week.

If you find this review to be helpful, please leave a thumbs-up. I also have a review page here: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviews

[h1] [b] Review recount of the 2007 Crysis [/b] [/h1]
I originally played and reviewed Crysis in 2016, on some PC that included a GTX 560 Ti. For those interested, the link to the original is here: https://steamcommunity.com/id/antwog/recommended/17300?snr=1_5_9__402

For the time, I thought Crysis was an enjoyable experience but could not play it on Ultra without performance issues. Have a look at my (back in the day) rating system, below.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th][/th]
        [th]Score[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Campaign[/td]
        [td]9/10[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay[/td]
        [td]7.25/10[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Graphics[/td]
        [td]8/10[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Overall[/td]
        [td]8.25/10[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

These ratings were based on a couple of key things from my original play, including:
[list][*]Campaign: ‘’The campaign [was] a great example of a story that starts slow, but builds to a climax. The setting of being on one island suggests a limited campaign, however, the great areas…on the island and in the island create a new variety of missions’’.
[*]Gameplay: “The gameplay is fluid and solid…[and] driving is a nice feature but clunky as the vehicle is very sensitive to player controls…[and] the issues I encountered…is the lack of ammo for an American gun and the very small variety of overall guns in the game”.
[*]AI: ‘’The main disturbance…is the sheer stupidity of AI. Some enemies would run in circles while ally team mates would be useless in completing objectives[.]’’[/list]
[h1] [b] What about Crysis: Remastered? [/b] [/h1]
The above is still fairly accurate, noting in the Remastered version that:
[list][*]The campaign features a nice and tight storyline and finishes really well, but I now think the North Korean invasion component was rushed and could have been fleshed out. I also found it a poor design choice that your allies are mostly unhelpful in the missions. 
[*]The AI is still really poor. They are still terribly accurate in their aiming and are still very glitchy, noting multiple times of enemies running into invisible walls, bunching together (i.e., in a doorway), and not reacting to the shooting and going into cover.[/list]
That said, Crysis: Remastered is sold on updated visuals and technological features and is optimised to current hardware. Playing on a PC with a i5-6600k, GTX 1070, and 16GB ram, I found the Remastered was optimised extremely well and I did not experience any framerate or stability (e.g., crashes) issues. The overall graphical fidelity is a broad improvement on the original and the Lingshan Island is still a beautiful sight, credited to an updated lighting system. 

While the graphics are broadly improved, the Remastered did not update all assets and objects (i.e., bag in opening scene, some characters), and therefore, the textures on these are disappointingly low-resolution and blurry. I am also surprised to find a number of bugs throughout my experience, including, but not limited to, the aforementioned AI scripting, as well as constant sound drop-outs during missions and the AI boss fight not triggering in the final mission, requiring a level restart(!).

[h1] [b] Conclusion on Crysis: Remastered [/b] [/h1]
I commend the legacy of Crysis I, and Crysis: Remastered is a nice trip down to memory lane, particularly in a nice campaign. But I am conflicted because the Remastered version was not overly a good experience. It adds a nice overall graphical upgrade and performance optimisation is fantastic (and I will note Patch 3 further optimises it), but it falls in several areas. 

First, it does not address issues from the original game such as AI scripting and if that is not fixable, I appreciate that. It is also unfortunate that the visual improvement does not impact all assets, resulting in a number of low-resolution characters and objects, and there are a high number of bugs and glitches throughout the game. On this basis, I do not recommend Crysis: Remastered.

Crysis Remastered is a polished version of the popular 2007 sci fi first person shooter game 'Crysis' developed by Crytek in 2007. The original game takes place through the eyes of a elite soldier nicknamed 'Nomad', a member of a U.S. elite military group named 'Raptor Team' sent on a hostage extraction mission on Lingshan islands after the U.S. archaeologists have made a world-changing discovery that is undergoing siege by the Koreans. Nomad, alongside with his colleagues, is equipped with the state of the art 'nanosuit', a exo skeleton that is designed to give soldiers a upper hand in every situation with unique abilities that makes them superhuman. The mission goes awry at the very start after your colleague was kidnapped and later found slaughtered alongside Koreans by a mysterious entity that later on is identified as a otherworldly organism named 'Ceph' with the mission of conquering the planet. It us up to Nomad to rescue the archaeologists and fight his way through war with the Koreans and the Ceph.

The original game was way ahead of its time with its beautiful graphics, outstanding lore and unique gameplay style that surpasses most games made today. It is a unique experience where you can do anything, the map is not designed linearly which allows the players to roam and do whatever they want. The soundtrack, the AI, the physics and much more are all beautifully made that gives lots of replayability as you can approach the game from any way, be it a silent sniper, onepunch man, rambo, there are always new ways to play the game. The characters are all unique with distinct personalities with lots of lore to each one, the nanosuit that makes us look cool and makes us feel powerful, the tank battles, the dogfights(aircraft fight) are all super fun and unique. The addition of mods just puts the cherry on top, with the large community designing new maps, new graphical mods and even a brand new game for the engine that the game is running on allows for many new opportunities which is why the original game is so beloved.

That being said, after the massive success over the years, Crytek decided to remaster the game, improving the already beautiful graphics, unnecessarily bringing over the suit modes from Crysis 2 and 3 which personally I favor but there are lots of people disappointed, since you are always stuck in power mode contrary to the 2007 version where the default was armor mode. Apart from the graphics, there isn't really much more added in the remaster. There are no new weapons, no new attachments, no new hostiles, no new areas to explore, no new missions, it is simply a graphical overhaul mod made by the original developers. Performance wise, to get over 100 fps you would have to lower the settings to low or medium as the improved graphics also take a toll on the GPU, and that makes the game unpleasant to look at the mass amount of jagged edges. The highest difficulty setting isn't that much of a challenge, the secondary objectives have no impact on the game, the AI sometimes doesn't behave as expected, they all negatively impact the game and make you question the whole remaster deal. The only better thing is the graphics at high settings, they look amazing, however, you would need to invest in a decent GPU as even the better GPU's struggle to run at the max settings.
I personally only enjoyed it as I am a huge Crysis fan, I am addicted to the amazing lore of the game and would like to take a different approach to the game after many years of not playing. 

Conclusion, I enjoyed Crysis as a way to experience the nostalgia and would recommend to play it, however, the remastered aspect is nonexistent, it is only made to test the developers graphical work. If you can get it for a lower price, the remastered is a good game but it is still disappointing, all the effort put into graphics are laid to waste as most people can't run the game with high settings with decent framerate.

On launch of the original game I remember this wasn't the best game around in terms of gameplay, gunplay world building or story but more a big tech demo for the CryEngine. It was the best looking game on the market for about ten years after and still, to this day, gives a lot of modern games a run for it's money in terms of how good it looks. But playing this remaster now and compared to the crap that has been released in the last few years that's saturated uninspired copy and paste game design I was actually enjoying this. It felt somewhat fresh being in a semi-open world game with tools at your disposal to play how you wanted to play and tackle objectives how you wanted to. It even got me pumped for Crysis 4 in the hopes they would go back to their roots and try a no BS open world game that doesn't force you to climb towers to view the world map or collect collectibles as side quests(Because these days collectibles are considered entire fucking side quests... I literally had to uninstall the game because it runs like utter crap. There's no way this should run as bad as it does. It's not even pushing the envelope in graphical fidelity. The physics engine is probably the exact same physics engine and version used in the original game in 2007, the HAVOC physics engine. HAVOC was ahead of it's time and it was a great physics engine but it was incredibly demanding. Now we have good physics engines that don't hobble performance. All I can think is the reason behind the performance drops for myself is the fact the buildings in view are straining the engine because of the physics engine. It still is incredibly good physics. You do not get this level of physics in any game released today even Frostbyte engine when it was top of it's game in Battlefield 1. The physics in this game calculates the weight, length, stress of structures and gives a realistic enough response when you remove supports from walls or roofs. It's still good but surely some sort of optimization could have been done here to fix performance and make the game playable? I refuse to believe they couldn't have done something 15 years later to improve performance in these instances.

It simply is unplayable as it is. Even for the €4 I paid for this it's not worth it.

If you've never played Crysis before, I think I would still recommend starting with the original version, but if you're a longtime fan this remaster offers an interesting new lens to play the game through and it never hurts to play Crysis again. I would probably give the game a sideways thumb if I could, since there are aspects both better and worse than the original, but considering owners of the original can get a pretty good discount it's worthwhile if you can get it cheap.

There are definitely some visual aspects that look a bit nicer. It's not revelatory but the new reflection effects to make certain things pop a bit better and I've always been of the opinion some of the original game's textures looked a bit over-sharpened, which the new volumetric fog smooths over nicely. The raytracing is pretty tasteful and in-line with the original art direction without being overdone, and there's some cool uses of it, such as being able to see your own reflection when you pick up a CRT Television. 

Character models seem largely the same but again, the facial textures don't seem as overdone on the sharpness filter and faces are a bit nicer to look at in general. For some reason the original Crysis didn't have anti-aliasing which struck me as odd even at the time given the game's intent of having every graphical technology under the sun. The blues and greens of the island seem to pop more as well, which is very pretty to look at and the water in particular looks great.

What is disappointing is that the Godrays seem toned down compared to the original. The scene in the first part where you finally step out onto the beach at sunrise was not only an iconic moment of the game, but a historic moment in game history itself that said "This is what games are gonna look like in 5 years" and the lighting just felt toned down here compared to the original which made that bit lose some of its edge. So while I do like a lot of what the remaster does, it's not a complete upgrade. 

Performance seems fine, but admittedly I'm running the game on the deliberately absurd "Can it Run Crysis?" mode, which on my 3090 tends to hover around 50fps which is pretty playable. I'm sure if I dialed it down to something more normal I would get a great framerate but my Tim Allen-like desire for MORE POWER UGH UGH UGH prevents me from setting my games to anything less than the maximum, and frankly if the newest edition of Crysis runs smoothly on Max it means that either it's time for a new Crysis or that society has come too far.

The default control scheme in this remastered edition is also [i]bizarre[/i]. Thankfully you can more or less set everything to how it was in the original but the default setting makes the game way more awkward to play. They tried to streamline the suit controls by basically having the powers activate when you do an action that can use that particular power. So for example, if you hold the jump or throw buttons you can do a "strength jump" or "strength throw". It works fine for the suit and cloaking (which is just the e key), but every time you sprint the suit goes into speedmode which wastes precious suit energy and it doesn't seem to let you just do a normal sprint. The streamlined controls worked in [i]Crysis 2[/i] and 3 because the whole game design was pared down for a more consolized experience, but trying to put a consolized control scheme in what is otherwise an unchanged full-fledged tactical PC shooter is just a mess of a default to ship the game with.

The placement of the hotkeys also means that the lean keys are mapped to T and H by default which is wildly inconvenient and I personally feel that making the deliberate choice of suit mode before jumping into combat was a deliberate part of the tactical considerations the original game wanted you to make rather than being able to just have everything at the press of a button. Again, you can set things back to how they originally were, and I get the feeling the streamlined setup was meant for the console ports then somehow got backported onto PC, but the default binds make the game significantly more clunky for no reason and deeply uncomfortable to try and use in combat. There's a weird weapon select menu if you press the 6 key which is absolutely [i]absurd[/i] but thankfully the original weapon switch keys are normal by default as well. That said though, the quick tips never change based on what your key setting are, so you might have the game telling you to press a button you mapped to something else, which feels unpolished.

Once you get over the jank of trying to remap the controls though, [i]Crysis[/i] is still as fun as ever. The game was derided by some at the time as a mere tech demo, but I find myself coming back to it again and again over the years even after the visuals begin to look dated in spots (and the original still mostly looks amazing). It's a true tactical sandbox, and while the game isn't "open world", each level is wide enough that you can approach from any direction and really get creative with how you want to handle a scenario. See a vehicle you like? Jump in and rampage through town. While there have been other sandbox shooters since, like the various [i]Far Cry[/i] sequels (and keep in mind [i]Crysis[/i] was the follow-up to [i]Far Cry[/i] 1, before Ubisoft took that series in a different direction), [i]Crysis[/i] and the [i]Stalker[/i] series are the only big ones that really do it this well. Your suit is powerful, but it won't compensate for bad decisions and the level design is just great. I do agree with the general consensus that the last quarter of the game isn't as good as the first due to a shift in the enemies you fight, but it's still fun. The gameplay feels pretty much the same, one or two weapons seem to have a punchier sound effect, but it's still the same old [i]Crysis[/i] and you don't have to twist my arm to much to get me on a new playthrough.

While [i]Crysis Remastered[/i] isn't perfect, it certainly isn't a [i]Crisis[/i] either. The visual refreshes are interesting enough to be worth going through again and I wouldn't be surprised if someone either mods the remaster to have the better aspects of the original, or ports stuff from the remaster into the original. It is a pretty glaring omission that they left out the [i]Warhead[/i] expansion which is fantastic in its own right, but it's nice to see [i]something[/i] being done with the series.  If you've never played the original, I'd again recommenced the original, but if you're already a fan and looking for something new, it's not a bad way to kill a few days.

Six dollars for an excuse to play Crysis again? Why the hell wouldn't I? People complain a lot in the reviews about how this remaster looks exactly the same as the original but I say it's hard to improve on perfection. The added mechanics that make the nanosuit controls the same as the game's sequels can thankfully be switched back to the classic ones (this game is like the Matrix, we don't need to pretend the sequels exist, right?) and it plays at better framerates than ever even on high settings. One downside I've seen is that if you've been playing the game for too long [spoiler]the larger sky flyer aliens[/spoiler] bug out and freeze, effectively becoming unkillable and making certain objectives unable to be completed without a full game restart but that is the only issue I had. Hell, the guys who did the remaster deserve all the props in the world - this is the first time I've played through Crysis and the last boss did not crash the game, not even once. That's saying something when it was a feature of the original.
Overall 10/10

Some sound effects are less annoying than in the original, others are more so. The game runs at a more stable framerate and loads much more quickly, but it looks uglier (even at the highest settings; it's a problem of art direction). There's been some gameplay tweaks, but also new bugs. For example, jeeps explode more quickly when shot in the gas tank and cloak is less of a power hog, but now crouching while prone makes you stand when you release crouch, and selecting the nanosuit mode with the mouse while crouching makes you stand. There's several things that mess with my muscle memory.
I don't mean to say that simply "they changed it, now it sucks", but the fact is that this version is not an objective improvement over the original, which I find disappointing, frankly, so I can't recommend getting it over the 2007 version, especially for anyone who's played that version several times.

[b]"Crysis" is considered to be a landmark in gaming history because of its advanced technical aspects that pushed the industry forward. Indeed for back then it is visually gorgeous (and has become even better in this remastered version), the sound design is fantastic and its physics was innovative. Artistically it is also good with great direction and some unique levels. Unfortunately some annoying glitches at navigation mechanics, bad optimization and mediocre enemies' AI won't let you enjoy it as much as you want. Nevertheless "Crysis" is a fairly good shooter that offers decent battles and allows you to choose between a tactical approach or the "destroy everything" route.


Manometer: 7/10[/b]


The good
- Gorgeous graphics ahead of its time. In this remastered version it has become even better with high resolution textures and revised atmospheric lighting.
- Great physics that were innovative for back then. You can interact, shoot, throw or shatter almost everything in a very convincing way. After a battle has finished, the landscape will be absolutely destroyed. A feature that even new games miss.
- Well paced battles with many things happening simultaneously. Good immersion level at a war situation.
- Gameplay allows you to choose between various approaches, either more tactical or entirely destructive. Cloak and shield powers of nanosuit are good additions that give the gameplay extra depth.
- Awesome survival atmosphere. Some parts have a weird dark, terrifying feeling. After a certain point it gets surreal and artistic.
- Fantastic sound design. Both environmental and battles' design feels natural and rich of sounds. Surround is well implemented and helps you understand enemies' direction.
- Interesting music that fits perfectly in each situation and gives an extra boost to the atmosphere.
- Nice animations especially at enemy creatures and at the protagonist's hands.
- It is very cinematic for its age. Great direction and camera movement with some nice timed events and special effects. Cool cut scenes too.
- You can drive a boat, a hummer, a tank and even fly an airplane.
- The story has a cliché beginning but after the middle it offers some interesting twists. It is still simplistic but descent enough for this king of shooter.
- It is well balanced. Normal difficulty will challenge you without being too hard.

The bad
- Navigation mechanics and interaction commands are not very responsive. Constant small glitches here and there (e.g. when crouching) will sometimes ruin the pace and the vibe you are into.
- Big loading screens and bad optimization for a game that old. You have to enable vsynch, otherwise the game will roast your cpu.
- Mediocre enemies' AI. Sometimes they react very slowly and others they run towards you instead of covering.
- Small variety of weapons and even fewer weapons' upgrades.
- You cannot save whenever you want. Sometimes there is a long distance to cover between two autosave points.
- The map is bad and most things on it are indistinguishable.
- The control mechanics of the airplane part are poorly implemented. Frustrating.
- It has small duration and abrupt ending. In fact there is no ending. I didn't like this weird final boss battle too.
Often get a lag when accel. Sometimes a fresh restart would do the job but not everytime.
Still best game.

Let's start it, by saying - if you've not played Crysis, I'd personally go with this version over the original, as it is more accessible, requires less tinkering, and plays slightly better.

However, as far as remasters go, this one is very disappointing. Ignoring the change of aesthetics at times, all of the issues with very much a junky AI are still here. The sound is as terrible as it ever was, with many sound glitches still present. And that horrible, directionless voice acting.... god, don't even get me started ("Perfect!" says Nomad happily, when it's supposed to be sarcastic "Perfect...", as implied by the situation and subtitles... ugh).

Anyway, graphics are still good, with occasional low-resolution textures, that have been carried from the original. The first Crysis always has been somewhat of a graphics demo, with everything else playing second fiddle and being just "acceptable" enough to pass. Sadly, with a move away from a limiting (in terms of lighting) forward rendering and modern techniques like Crytek's exceptional implementation of SVOGI, advanced ambient occlusion, and rework of materials to properly handle reflective surfaces, AND with raytraced reflections on top of it, one would hope that Crysis, stripped of its original limitations would be able to shine, once again. And while it's true that the number of vertices the engine can push at times is mindblowing, a lot of it is processing power wasted. The new tech works and it works great in interiors and areas with indirect lighting. But in an ironic twist, with all of the changes to aesthetics and the massive amount of geometry added, Saber - for whatever reason - opted out not to add and rework details in places, where that difference would be most noticeable, while simultaneously adding it in places, where performance might be precisely the heaviest, while at the same time, the graphical difference being the smallest. Working in game dev and being limited to DX11, taught me to be very careful with the number of objects used and to always look for a way to limit the number of draw calls, so I find it absurd that one of the first things done by Crytek / Saber duo, was adding a massive amount of foliage and additional objects, while simultaneously keeping it rendered in DX11 with interop with Vulkan only for rendering pass. This resulted in the game, in which performance is very much dependent on a single thread (again!) and where the rest of the threads barely does any work (again!). Worse yet, the raytracing is heavily limited, as it pretty much never reflects any characters or even physics objects (aside from the Nomad itself and that is only if you push Model detail to High... which is the same freakin' setting that affects the number of draw calls and will hit you the heaviest, even if you disable raytracing!). 

So, again - do I recommend Remastered? Only if you haven't yet played original Crysis. Cause despite my rant above, I think it is still an improved version of the original. Problem is, with how high original Crysis has set up the bar in terms of graphics, and how low it was in terms of pretty much everything else, it's disappointing to see remaster only lightly push it in terms of graphics and pretty much leave everything that was laying on the ground floor in 2007 as it was. This game needed a serious upgrade in terms of character models, character animations, sound, AI, and gameplay mechanics - and they've pretty much stayed as they ever were - on a "just good enough" level... for 2007.

Crysis with a new coat of paint, kind of. There are a number of features that are straight up missing that makes the first game more fun, biggest offenders being modding support and quicksaves. No leaning is not gone, it's just set to a really shitty bind by default. Outside that, the game's art style has also changed to something a lot more vibrant ([url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2604755659]although that's pretty easy to fix[/url]). The game also seems to nerf strength mode and speed mode even in classic mode. 

Only real improvements made to the game are optimization (though it doesn't feel like it once you set everything to very high), and the removal of SecuRom. Honestly I'd prefer if Crytek changed the Steam client of Crysis to the one they sell on GOG instead of spending all this time on an inferior port. Overall, I'd only recommend this game if you're a die hard Crysis fan that wants to see some extra eye candy. $15 isn't too bad of a price for this game, but I personally would not pay a penny more than that. If you don't have the first game, I highly recommend it still, just get it from GOG instead and play with mods.

Honestly I'm open to changing this review but only if strength and speed mode are reverted, gameplay changes like trees not breaking from punches are fixed, color settings and times of day are reverted to what they were in the first game, modding support is added, Warhead is included in the game, and further optimizations are made for multithreaded cpus. So yeah, just buy the GOG version and mod it.

Just when I wanted to reintroduce myself to the Crysis, I found out that the Remaster had been released, practically out of nowhere.

Let's go through the list:

+ Graphics. The tropical island is even more beautiful, than before.
+ Optimisation. With Ryzen 7 5800X and RTX 3070, I had constant 60+ fps on screen on max settings. I only downgraded the shadows to medium - I won't see any difference and this parameter is one of the hungriest in open world.
+ Multiplayer. Removed. Good, unless it's Doom or Quake, MP isn't allowed.
+ Achievements had been added.

- Glitches. Meh, a few, mostly objects getting stuck in geometry and troopers getting stuck pretty much everywhere. Notorious bug of the last chapter - cannon missing or refusing to lock on the mothership - has been fixed.

In the end, I liked the Remaster as much as I liked original. Unfortunately, I enjoyed 2&3 more than the first one, so I won't stay in this game for long.

Playing Crysis now in 2021 is a surreal experience and also an extremely enjoyable one. I can only imagine how awesome this game was back in the day (if you had the hardware to run it). The game looks great to me and I think it’s a fantastic mix between old and new aesthetics. I tried to play OG Crysis here on Steam a while ago but I couldn’t enjoy it. I did manage to get it working to some degree on Windows 10 but there was no proper controller support. The performance of this remaster is totally fine and the proper controller support is really what made the game accessible for me... finally. Crysis is a lot of fun to play, it’s like a military sandbox simulator with crazy Koreans and science fiction elements. I always liked the idea in the Crysis sequels, of fighting the soldiers first and then changing things up, to fight the aliens for the second half of the game. Playing through the remaster let me experience that idea in it’s first iteration. Which in-turn made me appreciate the sequels even more and what they were trying to achieve. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2615217603

The hardest difficulty setting (Delta) is great because it makes the game more immersive, without becoming annoying (except for the final boss). It’s really cool to actually need to use the suit powers and environmental cover while taking head-shots and feeling like a bad-ass ninja. There are some cool details on the hardest difficulty too like having to listen for grenades without HUD markers. While the human enemies only speak Korean which makes it harder to determine what they are doing.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2619720942

Where as the rest of the game is totally fine, the final boss is a fucking pain in the ass, on the hardest difficulty setting. Crysis is a lot of fun, just like the sequels and on the harder difficulty settings it’s even more fun, with the only exception to this being the god damn final boss. Which required me to die a lot and come up with a crazy trial and error strategy. There is also a fairly crappy level where you have to fly an aircraft and the controls are pretty bad but it’s actually not too difficult, once you get used to it. 

Crysis Remastered is also a relatively easy and fun game to get 100% achievements on (again with the exception of the final boss). A couple of the more advanced achievements are fairly bugged though, such as the ones for completing the game on the harder difficulties. It’s do-able but they are a bit janky and you need to work around this. Anyway.. this remaster made this fantastic game accessible to me, playing with a controller on Windows 10, for a very low price. 

I really enjoyed it and I highly recommend that you play it too!

This game was a great nostalgia trip that I really enjoyed. It clocked in at about 9 hours for me to do a complete play through of the storyline. 

It's fun to take a step back in time to experience one of the games that had a major impact on modern gaming, things like stealth kills are missing, there is no stupid "crafting" systems forced in, all progress is done simply by playing the story.

The open-ended yet "on rails" mission design is fantastic, I wish the modern Far Cry games would take a note from Crysis when it comes to this. Open world is fun to screw around in, but guided missions are much better for story telling.

The story itself was a pretty decent sci-fi, there is no forced romance or crappy plot written in. The characters are all fairly generic but that doesn't matter when you're sprinting at MAXIMUM SPEED to neck-slam a bunch of North Korean invaders.

Pros:
It runs, unlike the original which had to be tricked into thinking it's running on an FX processor to make it run on a Ryzen this one just works.
It looks ok, comparable to the first imo. Didn't put them side by side but it gives the same look and feel imo (no RayTracing active so no idea there, not on an RTX GPU).
The levels were not changed all that much, which is a good thing, plenty of other remasters/remakes tend to change level design for the worse (make levels more linear, remove stuff, etc).
The aim mode and crouch/prone are both hold and toggle at the same time which is kinda neat: if you hold aim it will go out of ADS once you let go, but if you just tap it once it will toggle on/off.

Cons:
Sometimes sounds cut out or in sharply, and here I mean stuff like combat music and so on. The sound for single/auto fire for some weapons is completely different, as if they forgot to update it for both fire modes (one is new, the other is the old one). Tap firing a weapon very quickly while it's in full auto will make the sound of the gun cut out and go silent while you keep tap firing, this only happens in full auto mode, you can tap fire away in single.
Quite buggy imo, things in the distance disappear quite quickly for me, helicopters are not visible more than 100m or so away, boats and even terrain objects like rocks behave the same. To be fair this may just be the LOD settings it applied automatically, speaking of which it put EVERYTHING on low on a gtx 1080 (the recommended is a 1660 Ti, so that's odd). At my settings (all on low, with textures on high), at 1440p it had anywhere between 90 and 120 FPS, usually stayed at 105-ish (on a Ryzen 7 2700x and gtx 1080 for reference).
Continuing the bug trend and avoiding spoilers: a specific enemy that has to be killed as a mission objective glitched out and was stuck under the floor, rendering it unkillable, loading a checkpoint did not work as he was already spawned and in the floor, will soon see if restarting the level fixes it. Which brings us to the next point, an autosave system has replaced the combo manual saves+autosaves that existed previously. Flexibility has been traded for ease of implementation as I see no other reason for this choice. A manual save system would allow both for replaying certain points in a mission if that's what you wish and for bypassing some of these bugs without having to restart the mission (as mentioned, sometimes the checkpoint is too close and you have to reload farther back).

So is it worth it? I think that if I knew all this I would've just reinstalled the old one and got a patch or something to get it working, and then wait for this to be fixed. When the bugs are gone maybe it'll be worth it, but until then, nah, even with a sale and as part of a bundle I felt like I should've bought a pizza with that money, would've had more fun playing the old one while eating it.

Right now I won't recommend it simply because one achievement is not working for some people including me. Till this is fixed this review stays negative.

EDIT: well it seems it's still possible to get the bugged achievement by deleting the save file, starting a new game and trying again.

Overall I guess the remaster is worth it for you if you never played the og game, or just want to play it with achievements or are just a big fan of the game without the biggest expectations  for the remaster. Otherwise probably not worth it.

To clarify, I had a good time with Crysis, but I'd give it a neutral review as based on pricing and what features were added/removed from the game.

Why bother revisiting Crysis? Aside from the obvious monetary incentives, what more was there for Crytek to really do with it? It doesn't seem like they made a particularly sincere effort to revitalise the game as it stands here, more-over just introducing a less buggy and somewhat more nuanced version of it: new nano-suit functionality and better optimisation on the whole. That's not to say it works entirely, there's still a great deal of bugs and the hardest difficulty seems, as times, pointlessly hard (with the checkpoint system doing absolutely nothing to better the matter). On top of that, they removed the multiplayer, Warhead is missing and you don't get the slick little map editor that came along with the original too.

But, it's good fun to come back here. At the discount price I got it for (first week and with Hunt), I feel more than fine with the amount of money that I put down on it. But, at £24.99, I can't really recommend. This game easily shows its age and for all the memorable set pieces, still feels half-baked without that nostalgia factor. I had a good time for the 7 hours it took to 100% this game on the hardest difficulty, but that's mainly due to it being a trip down memory lane. More than anything, it took me back to memories of early Crytek, Far Cry and the sense of expanse and open worlds in first-person shooters that would become massively popular in the mid-late 2010s. It's still here, but it's a lot more rudimentary and ultimately, Crysis feels dated in a bad way, at times.

TL;DR - buy it on sale if you loved the original. Don't buy at full price if you're new to the franchise or just wanting to play. You're better off modding the original.
