First of all let me say, I've played every single Crysis game previously. Played the original Crysis a long time ago. I remember it being super demanding back then. Now for the remastered version. This game is much more optimized. The graphical improvements are good if I say. Yeah the classic Crysis had this realistic less colorful vibe. That looked good no doubt. The remaster has more color in it. It still looks good. Actually doesn't look bad at all. Especially with all the ray tracing. But it didn't feel like a 2020 game to me. The visual quality of the remastered version looks more like it would be a game from 2014-15. I played straight for almost 9 hours. Finished the game in one run. It was fun. I liked most of it except the gun play feels a bit old and outdated. You could feel it that the firing mechanism is not on par with current gen games. They could've improved that. Also the AI was not that good. Weapon animations looks old. Stealth in this game is only for the name. It's impossible to go total stealth with Crysis. But the gun play didn't bother me much as I got used to it later on. 

I do recommend this game. If you haven't bought the original Crysis then you should definitely buy this one. If you already have the original Crysis then it's up to you. The two games are basically the same. The difference is, remastered version has better visuals and controls and it runs better. 

My rating for this game would be 7 out of 10 (judging by today's perspective). The original Crysis still gets a higher point because of the time it was released on.

I don't usually chime in on reviews as I'm not certain anyone really cares what my two-cents is, but having seen the laughable quality of those dropped for this game so far I actually felt obligated. So, here goes:

TLDR - If you played and loved Crysis at any point and would happily play through it again, get it. You'll love it. If you are a die-hard fan of the original and are generally into modding up retro versions of games more than seeing them remastered (admittedly a lot of remasters aren't worth the price tag), you probably will prefer your own version. If you like pushing your rig in the overclock and play things more for benchmarking, get it.

A BIT MORE DEPTH - 

Gameplay:

This is the classic Crysis experience. Don't feel a lot has been updated in AI, don't feel it really needed it. Yes, the AI programming is showing it's age a little but it's worth noting there are plenty games which are running much more simplistic AI which no one complains about. If you're used to playing on a gamepad, this has you covered. If you ever missed out on Crysis and are looking to dive in now you're safe in the knowledge this is an identical uplift and you won't be missing anything. If you were expecting more of a 'reboot' with redesigned levels, interactions, new story beats or characters then you probably won't get much out of this.

Graphics:

To anyone who has been running there mouth about how this is a downgrade somehow and the textures are worse and it looks like it's been put through a cartoon filter; put your money where your mouth is and upload some screenshot comparisons between the original and this remaster, as well as a screenshort of your settings and telemetry. I won't hold my breath because I can SEE the difference with my two EYES that were made for SEEING THINGS. 

All I can suggest? Your hardware isn't keeping up with the settings you WANT to be playing it on and you interpret this as a flaw somehow. The ray-tracing is transformative (first in gaming, there's a reason this has existed as theory for literal centuries and called "the holy grail" of lighting for decades). Textures are improved, effects are improved etc. I'm not writing a promo piece, just giving you the facts. I can understand how some may have been expecting MORE of an improvement and were disappointed with this. However, to suggest that there haven't been any improvements or that those that have been made have somehow worsened the experience is just dimwitted.

Remember, the max settings for this gane were designed to be mostly unreachable. Why do you think the phrase 'Can it run Crysis?' has been kicking around for almost a decade after it's initial release and lives on to this day? If you're stuck in a situation where your hardware no longer meets your expectations, you should also remember that the game looks pretty darn good on Medium settings, let alone High, Very High or Can it Run Crysis? I've played the original through on PC years ago, I've played it on the Xbox, Xbox One and One X for Crysis Remastered and now on PC again. I feel safe saying I'm quite familiar with this game and can see how it's been updated to take advantage of emergent technologies over the years.

Ultimately, it's not going to be to everyones tastes. I personally have always enjoyed it, some of my closest friends have never seen the appeal. Best recommendation on this aspect; if you like exploring pretty games, you'll probably get a kick out of this.

Last note on graphics, HDR is a very welcome addition. I remember being stoked about having a 4K screen and being more blown away by the change in colour depth with HDR than the resolution. 

Value:

At £20 on release for a remaster of this quality, can't really complain. Could be cheaper but a lot of other companies re-release games with NO significant upgrades for full price! I like using this for benchmarking and overclocking because it's perhaps unnecessarily taxing for what it's producing. My rig suffers less running Cyberpunk 2077 and I definitely feel there are a greater richness and abundance of concurrent effects running in that game at any given time than there ever are in Crysis. Good for stability testing. If you never played Crysis and are considering it, it's well worth the price. If you are a bit fatigued with it but are interested in the updated graphics, I'd probably flip a coin. The visual updates, if you are lucky enough to have the hardware to crank it a bit, are defo worth another full playthrough, but maybe only once if youi're not that into the gameplay any more. 

CONCLUSION - 

Make your own darn mind up! Take any passionate review, positive or negative, with a grain of salt as they might be giving you a biased opinion. I've tried to give you a brief rundown of my own experience in a way that'll help you decide whether it's worth your hard earned dollar or not. It all depends on what you value in your experience with a game and whether you feel there's enough here to take a gamble on

Crysis was huge deal back when it was first released. With it's gameplay and amazing graphics it gathered every gamer's attention. Playing it years later made me realize why Crysis is a special game. Most of the missions are open ended and lets you use both your weapons and nanosuit in any way you want. Unfortunately, the sandbox aspect of the game is removed in the later games but in Crysis 1 you are free to tackle challenges in any way you like. My roblem with the Crysis is that it's too short. You can finish the game under 6 hours. You get used to contols, the environment and all of a sudden you are in an alien ship and about to finish the game. I guess devs chose quality over quantity. At least, the game is awesome to play so you can start a second playthrough to increase the lenght. Overall Crysis is a masterpiece. If you haven't played it, you should definitely try it whether it's the remastered version or the original. It is one of the best FPS games on the market, and playing it's a fantastic experience.

Crytek sold out to Epic games.

[h1] Positives: [/h1]

+ No Denuvo DRM. [i] (Edit: The Epic Games version used Denuvo at launch and still hasn't been removed from that version for now.) [/i]

+ Support for Achievements.

+ DLSS Support for Nvidia RTX Cards.

+ Still plays like Crysis (2007) overall, despite the negatives I’m about to list from what I’ve experienced and read from other people.

[h1] Negatives: [/h1]

- No Cloud Saving Support. [i] (Edit: Subjective opinion since some people felt it isn't necessary, due to the campaign's short length but I personally disagree.) [/i]

- No Multiplayer and Crysis Warhead is still treated like the red-headed stepchild of the Crysis Family.

- It’s based off the PS3/XBOX 360 version which means the benefits of being able to quicksave are completely gone and now, the nanosuit powers have been nerfed both in effectiveness and how they control/feel.

- Apart from SVOGI and Ray Tracing, the “remastered” graphics artistically look much worse and uglier overall than the original PC version. Said Ray Tracing isn't worth the hit to performance since it only focuses on reflections.

- Optimisation on PC is still busted thanks to Cryengine still only using single threaded performance from the CPU. This results in constant stuttering even at the lowest settings while using v-sync. 

- Lingering bugs that aren’t fixed in the Epic Games version still persist in the Steam version.

- Now uses EOS (Epic Online Services) despite strictly being a single player experience.

- Casts doubt that the remastering efforts for Crysis 2 and 3 won’t be a disaster, since both of them will be still Epic Games Store exclusives for a year.  

- All of these negative aspects, combined with no actual improvements equate to making the 20% discount at launch and an extra 30% for those who own the original PC version, still a complete rip-off for what you’re paying for vs what you get.

[h1] Overall: [/h1]

[b] Buy Crysis (2007) instead and use graphical mods if you want a superior remastered experience. Do yourself a favour and save your money from buying this shoddy excuse of an official “remaster.” [/b]

After playing through the whole game, I have noticed a number of bugs that I would hope the devs address in an update. Let me go over some of the good things then I can cover any other issues that I came across.

-----Pros-----
Game can be set back to classic mode:
By default the game is set to run more like the sequels rather than the original. So we will need to go into settings to make some changes. First, we need to get the power wheel back so we need to go into Settings > Game Settings > Game Tab >  Check Classic Nanosuit Mode. Next, we will need to change some keybindings. By default, the Q/E are set to Armor/ Cloak mode and the Left/Right lean are set to T/H. These changes should be all you need to do to get the controls back to the original.

Powers seem to be relatively untouched:
From my tests the powers seemed to be the same. Another Review mentioned that the speed mode was heavily nerfed. However, this does not seem to be the case because after running from various points and comparing them to the Original the energy consumption was almost exactly the same. Testing of other modes such as Armor, Cloak, and Strength mode all seemed to be the same as well in terms of energy consumption.

Combat:
When fighting enemies, combat still seems to be the same for the most part. Shooting an enemy in the head kills them instantly no matter what difficulty you have the game set at, which is nice. I would rather not have enemies be bullet sponges.

-----Cons-----
No quick saves:
Going through the game on Delta difficulty makes it very apparent that quick saves are missing. If you die you can only use the last autosave that was made which can set you back a good amount. You are at the game's mercy at when it decides to make a save point which seems to be at scripted areas or distances from an objective which seems to be the same as the original. I don't know why quick saves were removed but that seems like a really dumb decision.

Graphical bugs:
In the first level, I noticed that there were some assets that were floating above the ground. Some examples are rocks or grass that will be floating a couple of inches off the ground. The grass was less obvious until I was looking at it from a different angle.

Audio bugs:
There were a whole lot of audio bugs that I found in the game.
- Cloaking and then using the binoculars makes audio stutter
- Cloak distorts the audio of surrounding assets like the chicken. It deepens and slows the clucks down like it was being put through slowmo.
- Stepping on wood sounds like you are breaking planks. I discovered this while traversing one of the hanging wooden bridges.
- Artillery at the beginning of the "Assault" mission is basically non-existent unless you are standing right next to where the explosion is happening.

AI pathing:
AI pathing seems to be an issue in this version of the game. I have had many times where the AI would be trying to walk up the side of a mountain to get to me, trying to go through walls, and even just going a slightly different direction than where I was located.

"Fatal" error bugs:
On the mission onslaught I ran into a pretty error that I have never seen before in the original. After you get the Gauss rifle from the VTOL drop off, you come across this "checkpoint" with like 10+ guards. When I died here, the game just stopped with a black screen and gave me two error windows and asked if I wanted to Abort, Retry, or Cancel. I selected Retry for both popups and the game seemed fine until I killed all the enemies at the checkpoint. Four soldiers in particular just existed...You couldn't kill them and they were just walking back and forth really fast.

Is it worth $30? ehhh not really. I think if you own the original on Steam and with the Launch discount you can get it for $15 which seems like a more reasonable price.

While crysis is a good game this just isn't worth it. 

Visuals:  
It looks better than the original but the performance you get doesn't match the quality of the visuals.   It is also very inconsistent, some things look great while others look like they reused original textures.   It creates this unbalance that looks worse than either would on their own.   Like the way things are destroyed looks really really bad and cheesy.     On top of that even with a top of the line graphics card there is a good amount of studdering.  

Gameplay:
The gunplay itself is excellent and the guns are fun to use.    The enemies in general are fairly tough although that is one of my major complaints is when the enemies literally take more shots to kill than they can kill you in when your the one wearing the high tech nanosuit.  Balance is all over the place for the most part, some things were stupidly easy and others ended up overly difficult.    There isn't a good difficulty curve to the game it just randomly spikes and dips.  You get sections that are a joke followed by an overly difficult part and then another overly easy section.      Balance is utterly broken at times and some things are just flat out bugged.   For example, on the final fight it is possible to get chain frozen until you die which is just annoying and makes the fight a chore instead of being fun.       Enemies seem to sometimes just know your location and will just look straight at you if you get too close even with stealth and crouched and the lack of a takedown makes actual stealth gameplay suck since you can't really misdirect enemies or take down enemies without alerting everyone around.  The strength options are completely useless in the game and honestly even the defensive shield gets chewed through so quickly by the more dangerous enemies that it is borderline useless.   On the other hand you can completely cheese the stealth mechanic and enemy AI with a bit of range by shooting from stealth hiding behind a tree and stealthing again.     It made the gameplay balance just feel terrible and should have been something you would have expected to be fixed in the remaster.  

Sound: the sound is pretty much the same as the original and not that good.  There is nothing to say here, it sounds like a 15 year old game.  It honestly didn't seem like they did anything with the remake in that department.

Starting with the positives: 
- The game now looks like how I remember it. Visually it's been brought to the 2020s and my nostalgia is happy about that.
Sadly thats it. End of the positives. (comparing to the orignal of 
course, not making a review about Crysis as a game. Love this game)

The negatives:
- The mouse sensitivity is insane. Even on the absolute lowest setting its still twice as high as what I play normally, and I know a lot of FPS gamers who play significantly lower sense than me. I was struggling more with controling my character than I was with the actual enemies. 
- Which brings up the second point: the AI is terrible. Seemingly completely unchanged from the original, but in the mean time us gamers have all gotten used to for more responsive and interesting enemies.
- Movement feels sluggish and unresponsive. Its like moving through syrup. I don't recall the original feeling like it was constanly holding me back. Even with speed mode enabled I don't feel like a fast and deadly super soldier, instead I feel I'm obese and cannot run properly.
- Various performance issues. Poor optimisation on some features, frame drops and the likes. I didn't play long enough to really give detailed feedback here.
- A big one. Audio. WHY, just why, do they put all this effort into visual improvements but apparently haven't put a single minute of effort into actual audio improvements. These are the same gunshot sounds, impact sounds and explosions from 15 years ago and many of them sounded unimersive and unrealistic even then. Even the most beautiful environment won't feel immersive if it sounds 20 years dated.
- Not so important for me personally but still relevant: the multiplayer content was cut out entirely.
